       Sadly, I have got cauught up in the whirlwind of the 'interesting times' and am closely following the Seattle WTO story: I feel that what happened is one up for the good guys. Perhaps we ought to institute a special status, with special title, for anyone who writes a story of treatise of over one page, in length, using Glosa!  Zamenhof did, for Esperanto.

*   Boni Eforti, Marcel,

    Tu monstra posi u major faceta te gene ski de Glosa: uti id.

    E tu akti so, fo boni.  Per tenta expresi tu auto, uti Glosa, tu fu este plu verbi loka-se, ko maxi gru.  U-ci este kresce ko praxi.

    Qe, tu gene dificili ex cogita uti Deutschland-lingua, e, seqe, kogita uti Glosa?

   

    Koncerne u re-loka de plu existe Reti pagina intra tu auto Reti-lo, u-ci akti habe fo logika: si tu ne traduce un info in Deutschland-lingua, qo-pe fu akti id?  Kron tu traduce plu pagina ex Richmond, U.K. - posi ex Paul Bartlett Reti-lo - place dona atributi a plu autori-pe.

    Si tu uti plu itema ex mi Reti-lo, posi tu fu inklude u nota de mi, sed solo pro plu raisona de histori.  

    Qe, tu habe este ke un inklude de "Seminar #1" fu auxi plu futura stude-pe de Glosa, intra deutschland?  Tu sio posi don u lista de plu beneficia stude-ma pro plu Deutsch stude-pe de Glosa.

  _=_=_=_=_=_


&   A Good Effort, Marcel,

    You demonstrate possibly the main aspect of learning Glosa: using it. 

    And you do so very well.  By trying to express your-self using Glosa, you will feel the words locate themselves with best fit.  This feeling grows with practice.

    Do you have trouble thinking in German, and then, thinking in Glosa?


    Regarding re-locating existing Web-pages in your own Web-site, this action is very logical: if you do not translate this information into German, who will do it?  When you translate the pages from Richmond, U.K.  

- possibly from Paul Bartlett's Website - please give recognition to the authors.  

    If you use items from my Web-site, possibly you will include a note about me, but only for reasons of history.

    Do you have the feeling that inclusion of "Seminar #1" will help future Glosa students in Germany?

  [N.B. The languge of Linguistics is not fully worked out for Glosa, but Seminar #1 should translate readily into German .. if you think it fits in a Web-page.]

_A first Seminar on Glosa____________________________R. Gaskell Sept,1995_
               (With apologies, in English)
WORDS
        Words in Glosa represent concepts, and are really `concept/words.'
They represent ideas, but, depending on their position in the sentence,
and their relationships to other words, they may represent that idea in its
solid form (noun), active form (verb), or as a modifier of another idea
(adjective, adverb).

        The words do not change for reasons of grammar (system for getting
understanding from words): this means that words can be used, within
reason, as any part of speech, but have no letters added to indicate this
useage (no Part-of-Speech markers); also, the words which act as verbs,
`verbs', have no endings added to them (no inflections) to give added
understanding of how, or when, the action is taken.

        The order of the words (syntax) gives us the meaning in Glosa; the
language can be described as having `syntax-based grammar.'

PHRASES
        The phrase (small group of words) is the basic unit of sentence
construction in Glosa.  A small group of words might include a thing and
some description of it (noun phrase), or the group might include an action
and some modifications to this action (verb phrase).  A small group of
words at the start of a Glosa sentence might qualify the action of the
sentence (adverbial phrase).

        Within each phrase, each word is modified by the one before it, and
there is a gradual increase in importance of the words, with the main
concept/word (`noun' or `verb') as the last word of the phrase.
                e.g.  the three fast, loud red cars                  NP
                      plu tri celero fo-sono rubi vagona

                e.g.  were quickly end excitedly talking loudly      VP
                      pa du celero e excita fo-sono dice

                e.g.  while running     (relates to  --->  verb)     AdvP
                      tem kursi

        In speech, phrases are said as one group, often with a raising then
lowering of intonation (pitch), from start to finish; in written form, if
it seems necessary for the understanding of meaning, the start and finish
of phrases, is indicated using punctuation (commas).

CLAUSES
        A clause is a larger group of words containing two (NP + VP) or
more phrases, and such a simple two or three phrase clause can make up the
whole sentence (major clause).  However, a clause - which always includes
at least one verb phrase - might add meaning to the action of the
sentence (Adverbial Clause), might give more description to one of the
things in a sentence (Adjectival Clause), or it could be a group of words,
including a `verb,' used in the place that you would normally find a noun
phrase (Noun Clause).

      e.g.  The boy arrived.              U ju-an pa ariva.            MC

      e.g.  The girl went home.           U ju-fe pa ki a fe domi.     MC

      e.g.  The man will eat the meal.    Un andra fu vora u vora.     MC

      e.g.  She spoke so loudly that she was heard.
            Fe pa ta sono dice ke fe pa gene ge-audi.                AdvC
                          ~~~~ <-- ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

      e.g.  The girl went home after she had eaten a good meal.
            U ju-fe pa ki a fe domi, po fe pra vora u boni vora.     AdvC
                       ~~   <---     ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
      e.g.  The boy, who was fat and badly dressed, arrived.
            U ju-an; qi pa es paki e mali ge-vesti, pa ariva.        AdjC
              ~~~~~ <-- ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
      e.g.  I like to get away from the house.
                  (getting)
            Mi amo gene ab u domi.                                     NC
                   ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
      e.g.  The farmer hoped that it would rain.
            Un agri-pe pa spera: ke id sio pluvi.                      NC
                       ~~~(V)~~  ~~~~(O)~~~~~~~~

SEQUENCE IN A CLAUSE
        The normal sequence in Glosa is the same as in English:-
 Main Clause =   noun phrase    -    verb phrase     -    noun phrase
                  (SUBJECT)            (VERB)              (OBJECT)
            Doer of the action    Action being done    Thing acted upon
           e.g.     He                 posts               a letter.
                    An                 posta               u grama.

        There are three main variations to this: clauses with no object
(intransitive verb); clauses where, for reasons of style, the speaker,
or writer, wishes to emphasise the object by placing it first (Passive
Voice); and Noun Clauses which have no subject (infinitive verb).
           e.g.    She (NP)    sang. (VP)                 Fe pa kanta.
                 (SUBJECT)    (VERB)

           e.g.   The letter       was posted        by the man.
                   U grama      pa gene ge-posta     ex un andra.
                               (did get got-post)
                   (OBJECT)         (VERB)                (SUBJECT)

           e.g.                  - running (=to run)     on wet grass
                                    kursi              epi ge-hidra gra
                                    (VERB)                 (OBJECT)

        Because its grammar depends on the word order, Glosa works best if
we keep to the normal (S-V-O) structure in clauses.  In poetry and fiction,
however, the stylistic variations are necessary.

FUNCTION WORDS
        These are the small words that are not concept/words, but which
join these words together (conjunctions), lead us into a phrase or clause
(prepositions), create negatives, introduce questions, or modify the timing
of an action when placed before a `verb' (tense particles).  There are also
the small words placed before `nouns' to tell us that they are things, and
how many, or how much, of them there are (determinants).
        Joining words:  e, sed, pluso, alo, ni

        Prepositions: tem, a, ex, de, anti, seqe, po, pre, vice, krom ....

        Negatives: ne, nuli, no-, ni ... ni, nuli-

        Questions: Qe, qestio, qod, qo-

        Tense particles: pa, fu, du, nu, pra, sio, ge-, gene

        Before `nouns': u, plu, plura, uno, vario, poli, oligo, u mero de
         (determinant)

SENTENCES
        Putting all the above together, in Glosa, as in English, sentences
can be made up of various combinations of phrases and clauses - as long as
the Subject-Verb-Object rule is observed.  In Glosa, also, there is the
added requirement that words in phrases follow the rule of increasing
importance, with the main concept/word last.

        If the sentence is made up of phrases only, there is a single
`verb', and the sentence is described as a Major Clause.  If there are two
or more `verbs', then the `verb' describing the main action forms the Main
Clause, and the other clauses (NC, AdvC, AdjC) are called Subordinate
Clauses.  The whole sentence can, however, still be called the Major
Clause.
        The secret of good sentence formation is in using well-formed
phrases to make up the sentences and their constituent clauses.

PRECEDENCE IN PHRASES
RULE: In a phrase, a word is modified by the word in front of it (its
        precedent.)
RULE: In a normal sentence (Major Clause), there is a tendency for the
        first noun phrase (SUBJECT) to modify the verb phrase (VERB), and
        then, for the verb phrase to modify the second noun phrase (OBJECT).
RULE: A modifying clause (Adjectival or Adverbial) follows directly after
        the concept/word that it modifies; this structure is indicated
        by the placing of a semi-colon (;) or possibly a colon (:) before
        the new clause.

 In a noun phrase, the sequence is:-

           determinant  -  number  -  quantity  -  modifier(s)  -  noun

        e.g. plu tri no-ge-numera, fo sono, no-puri ju-an
             the three uncounted, shouting, dirty boys

           Note.  The concept/word used as a noun is the only element of
              a noun phrase that is essential.

 In a verb phrase, the sequence is:-
                                                    |   verb
  negative - tense - modifier(s) - auxiliary verb - |      OR
 particle                                           | verboid + amplifier

                     e.g. ne pa hedo, no-soni tenta | kursi
                                                    | ki ana

                       did not happily, quietly try | to run
                                                    | to go up

           Note, again.  The concept/word used as a verb is the only
               element of a verb phrase that is essential.

 %%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%

To: "David Porter" <David{at}eastholmeonsea{dot}freeserve{dot}co{dot}uk>
Subject: [glosalist] Re: From DP Continuing discussion re Glosa
From: Robin Gaskell <rgaskell{at}zeta{dot}org{dot}au>
Date: Mon, 31 Jan 2000 12:12:03 +1100
Cc: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au

At 12:09 29/01/2000 -0000, you wrote: 

>>>>

<excerpt><smaller>Hello Robin!

Thank you for your interesting observations    .....    feel that there
is enough to learn without having to overcome contradictions and
inconsistencies - that was my reaction anyway. 

</smaller></excerpt>** Hi David,

    The main problem, for me, with these base-level annoyances in the
Glosa lists, is that I do not have a printing press, and that while
refining these matters - to "standardise" Glosa - I had a computer
wipe-out with a virus.

It was complicated, and I was off the Net for a month, which was enough
to take the impetus away from the Glosalist, whose members were working
on it.

    So, For the many non-Networked Glosa-pe printed paper copies of the
dictionaries is all they have.  Howevber, for the Netted Glosa-pe, we can
change the spelling and remove unwanted synonyms, but this was taking a
long while to reach concensus. 

    Also, we had the other problem of 'copyright' and the authors'
dominance and moral suasion.  But, for financial reasons, Clark and Ashby
while joining the Internet, were not active on it, and did not join the
Glosalist discussions.

    So, I was creating what could almost be seen as a parallel
administration of Glosa, and I needed to maintain good connections with
the authors at the same time.  That was just the way it was.

    Now, however, Glosa's basic plan is just as good as it ever was, but
the authors are not able to maintain as active a role as they had.  So, I
could exert a stronger influence in the works: I could buy a laser
printer, so that dictionaries I print will not run when wet (as
bubble-jet does); and I could complete the "Glosa 2500 Learner's
Dictionary" that was nearly ready when I got virussed: also I could
become much more active in the creation of learning materials, such as
cassettes and instruction books.  But ....

    Just when I started bouncing back from the wipe-out, other ..
non-linguistic .. problems arose on the horizon.  Had there been no worry
about the survival of basic Democracy, I would have happily put all of my
effort into getting Glosa off the ground.

    I am not sure how much you know about the MAI, G7 or WTO, but there
really was good reason for all of those people moving into Seattle to
alert the world to its perilously dangerous situation.  I an afraid that
political forces are far stronger than those of language reform, and that
we will probably see Capitalism collapse - as cataclysmically as did
Russian Socialism - before we see world leaders decide to act on the IAL
hypothesis.  I am working on the question of which system follows
Capitalism when it has been discredited.



<excerpt><smaller>  I accept your point regarding creativity (where would
humanity be without it?) and if the language should ever become accepted
and used as an IAL then change, innovation, creativity should follow
naturally (as happens with languages anyway). 

</smaller></excerpt>**   The bad news is that there isn't much spare
creativity about: most creatives are busy exploiting their imaginations
as song-writers, pop musicians, advertising copy-writers, hack
journalists, novel-writers, etc.

     Very few are employing their creative abilities altruistically to
prevent our civilisation from falling into the abyss.  In a round-about
way, I am saying that I have been distracted, by events, from applying
myself single-mindedly to the success of the IAL.


<excerpt><smaller>  Whilst Glosa is in its infancy (with regard to
becoming known and accepted) I do believe that it should be made as
simple as possible and presented in such a way that its functionality
cannot be criticised. 

</smaller></excerpt>**   And it is obvious, as well.  The authors did
simplify Hogben's pattern considerably, and Glosa is now recognised as
the Planned Language with th most simplified structure.  But, on
functionality, the authors misjudged the need for regularity on the part
of the majority of mankind.  They did not standardise the dictionary
spellings; but, for reasons of cost, kept printing the same wordlists ..
even though the lack of standardisation was reported, to them, as being
irksome to many learners.


<excerpt><smaller>  Faulty dictionaries, contradictory word endings, more
than one word to represent a definitive idea (in the basic 1000 words at
least) allows areas for criticism which could be avoided without too much
trouble.   It is easy to criticize of course but there are other areas of
concern to me.   Firstly I don't really understand why punctuation needed
to be changed from the conventional (when writing Glosa as I did some
five years ago I found myself keeping to conventional punctuation - and
only used colons and semi-colons where I would normally have done when
writing English.

</smaller></excerpt>**    This is a tricky one.  However, I suspect that
there is such a thing as a "Grammar of Punctuatuion."  It is possible,
that, as evolved as it is, an also as conventionalised as it is, English
punctuation might be right for the way English works, but not necessarily
for the ways some other languages work.

      I tried to understand what Ron Clark was doing, when he introduced
specialised punctuation rules for Glosa, and I try to apply them .. to
see if they are 'funcional.'  When I 'think in Glosa' I use the Ronald
Clark system of punctuation - more or less; and, when I think in English,
i tend to use a standardised version of English punctuation.  And I note
that when I give Glosa and English versions of the same sentence, they
might be differently punctuated.

      As an explanation, not an excuse, I would mention that Glosa,
having a 

syntax-based grammar with uninflected words, means that sometimes the
puntuation needs to do some of the grammatical work: I liken it to the
use of a shoehorn - to make sure that things go into the right place, IE
are understood by the reader to articulate in the way intended by the
writer.  Then again, in spoken Glosa, vocal inflection gives us the
internal structure of the sentence, much as punctuation does in written
text.  So, in Glosa, I might say that good punctuation is more important
than it is in English.  There probably is a clear relationship between
written punctuation and the vocal inflection that it is used to indicate.
 You are having trouble with the fact that Glosa and English have a
different set of ground-rules to indicate this relationship.

      Although Ron did not express it as functionally as I do, Glosa
phrases are 'flagged' with a starting comma, and Glosa Clauses are
'flagged' with a starting semi-colon.  This is not a hard and fast rule,
so that semi-colons can be elided to commas; and commas can be elided
out.  However, where it seems necessary to mark the sentence structure
for reasons of clarity - and with Glosa's simplified form, this may
become necessary - then the mechanism, to do so, exists.

      Most English-speakers claim that an excess of semi-colons makes a
sentence look ugly.  And this may be so.  But were the language taught
functionally, then learners would happily use the "start of clause" mark,
so that the reader had no trouble in understanding the structure of his
sentence.


EG  Fe pa ki a fe domi; qi habe loka to u buta de u via.


   She went (to her) home, (which is) located at the end of the road.


    Fe pa ki domi; loka to u buta de u via.


In Glosa the same functional punctuation, the semi-colon, is used
whether, or not, there is elision.  While I could have 'puristically'
placed a comma after LOKA to indicate the start of a subsidiary phrase,
this structure was obvious, and I elided the comma.

    Had Ron Clark thought differently, he mght have invented unique
punctuation marks for Glosa - to avoid confusion with the established
usages for the traditional marks of English.

    Since having thought about the 'function' of punctuation, as it
applies to Glosa, I have loostened up my own markings in normal English
.. especially on the Net, EG

   raining ^cats and dogs^

   well .. only at Christmas

   he *really* got angry

   then, I knew ... it was the flat battery

   couldn't move; but, when it growled


<excerpt><smaller>   Also I found it rather annoying when reading Plu
Glosa Nota to come across words that I couldn't fathom the meaning of
which didn't appear in the dictionaries.    Subsequently advice was given
to use an Italian dictionary to supplement Glosa vocabulary - do you
think that is sound advice - what are the alternatives with regard to
expanding the vocabularly? 

</smaller></excerpt>**   Agreed it was a bit silly, however I use mainly
the Latin dictionary for word divination and creation, and on rare
occasions I consult the Greek one.

     Italian is relevant to pronunciation: borrow a cassette of spoken
Italian, and you hear Glosa's sounds.


<excerpt><smaller>   Also what do you think about the practice of naming
days and months by numbers?   Is it not just a bit too 'clinical' - too
detached?  (I'm having difficulty in expressing conveying what I mean
here).   Days and months tend to have recognisably internationalised
names and are usually learned without too much difficulty - personally I
know I would have found it easier and quicker to have learned names
rather than to have tried to work out which day di sixa represented or
which month is meno seti.   The dictionaries do give some names but not
all. 

</smaller></excerpt>**   While it might be more human to have folksy
names for days and months, it is probably more 'ecumenical' to
standardise the calendar mathematically, at least for beginners; once
people have moved up to a dictionary with synonyms, they then should have
no problem in being understood using either "Januari" or "Mo 1".


<excerpt><smaller>  I suppose that my experience with Esperanto showed me
the advantages of a well controlled language although this too can be
problematical if "conservatives" refuse to budge when innovation is
called for - and I am referring to the reluctance to accept change
concerning  the accented letters which  many Esperantists wanted to
abolish so as to make the language more user friendly, particularly  with
regard to the computer.

</smaller></excerpt>**   Yes, we have some conservatism in Glosa too: as
Esperantists think accent marks are OK, some, in Glosa, think variable
spellings are OK.  But full standardisation is needed for any language
that is intended for use within all cultures!  This was, originally to
have been achieved by the Glosalist.

<excerpt>  

<smaller>Yes, I am still interested in the Glosa social invention - I am
a "one world" person who does not consider that he has a country - the
absolute opposite of a patriot/nationalist.   Part of my
political/economic/social outlook embraces the need for an IAL (or as I
mentioned before any language that may be universally acceptable).  

</smaller></excerpt>**   Interesting themes here: a community-based
society probably is more likely to be 'patriotic' than 'globalised'.  And
centralisation of power and wealth are proving to be major evils of this
Later Phase of Capitalism.  So, does Interlingualism favour the
centralisation of power, or does it maintain the strength of community?


<excerpt><smaller> At the moment my wife and I are struggling to learn
some Spanish -and it is because of this (added to some disillusion with
Glosa for reasons stated)  that I put Glosa on the back burner for a
while.   We go down to Spain for a camping holiday during Feb & March so
for that period I will not be available.   This email was started a few
days ago but then put aside whilst I endeavoured to download your
seminars - I could't transfer them to 'word' - had to 'phone my son who
knows about these things  - anyway to cut the story short I got at them
through 'notepad' this morning but I will not  have time to digest them
properly before going away so will print them off and take them  with
me.

</smaller></excerpt>** Happy travelling in Spain, and success with the
language.  Spanish is the major second language in the southern states of
the USA.  I have tended to keep in ASCII, where possible; perhaps I will
need to adopt a newer w.p. convention.

<excerpt>Wordpad is much better than Notepad.

  

<smaller>I see with interest that you are a jazz enthusiast and I am also
(where trad is concerned).   Unfortunately I do not have your gift of
being able to play a musical instrument and my singing (in or out of the
bath) brings on an amused smile from my wife.   We do manage to  get away
to a few jazz weekends during the year and we regularly attend the
monthly jazz session at the quaintly named venue in Norwich called  the
'Norfolk Dumpling' .   Unfortunately we will miss the next three sessions
two of which are good continental bands.      I look forward to hearing
from you.

Saluta.   

</smaller></excerpt>**   It's more of a fading memory these days.  When
Peace returns, I will retire, and probably start playing again.


Saluta

  Robin Gaskell

Qe, "es" ne habe idea in Glosa?  Mali fortuna.  Qo-ka?  
In England-lingua "to be" es no-dina. 
  ("How many are there?": "there" es nece.)
In Deutschland-lingua "sein" es ma no-dina.
  ("Wieviele gibt es?": "sein" sio es tro ma-dina.  Mu
  ne pote uti id.  Mu nece uti "geben" (="to give") alo
  "existieren" (="to exist"). Mi es tristi de id.)
Sed in Latin-lingua "esse" es ma dina.  U-la mi frase 
sio es posi. 
Un Rasia-pe ne uti u no-dina "es". An lase ab.
  ("Eta on Anton." - This (is) him, Anton.)
Mi puta; Glosa habe plu oligo, elementa e dina verba.

Hi Marc .. OR .. Karo Marc (as we say in Glosa),

At 01:14 11/02/2000 -0800, you wrote:

>Dear Robin,

>  Thank you for the Glosa material which I just picked

>up. My e-mail address is marcwathen{at}yahoo{dot}com .

*  Thanks for the feedback.  And, yes, email is quicker, and allows the tranfer of more data. 


>  I was surfing the Web and came across your

>information. I am interested in auxiliary languages as

>I started studying Esperanto a couple of years ago. I

>took a 10 lesson correspondence course in Esperanto,

>and I also took a course offered by the local

>Esperanto group here.

>  Before I got connected to the Internet, I thought

>that Esperanto was the only auxiliary language. I did

>some research on the Web and found out about

>others-Glosa,Ido, Interlingua,etc.

*   The list is almost endless; it more, or less, began in the Renaissance, with the members, of the newly set up Royal Society, deciding there ought to be a language for ALL scientists.

    Now it seems like a bazaar, from which one selects the language one likes.

    However, there is a catch: nobody can decide which is the best of the Planned Languages; but, if the world is to have _A_ Second Language, only one of them can be successful in achieving this quest.


>   How does Glosa compare to Esperanto? 

*   For your purposes, travelling widely, and meeting new people - with whom you can communicate directly - Esperanto WINS.

    If, on the other hand, you take a longer, possibly more intuitive, view, you could see that the race is not yet won, and that Glosa could be a more suitable modern language.

    Esperanto has the infrastructure, a vast library of books, and an army of speakers.  The only drawback is that it is a bit hard to learn. With 99% of the world's population ignorant of the International Auxiliary Language (IAL) hypothesis, either way, Interlanguage is still not even a minor area of human endeavour.


>What are the advantages of Glosa over Esperanto?

*   Mainly intellectual, and possibly psychological.  Glosa, designed a century after Esperanto, embodies many of the new views on Linguistics.

So, Glosa is like English, which, of the Euro languages, has the least morphological grammar .. but it progressed with this trend to the Chinese position, where there is virtually no grammatical change to the words. 

    If your psychology sets you up to follow cleary defined patterns and rules, then you will be in tune with the way Esperanto works; however, if you vere towards the creative use of language, you are likely to appreciate the "open plan" nature of Glosa.

    The Esperanto dictionary has been through a number of revisions and is fairly well settled; the Glosa dictionary (Glosa 6000), is reasonably well set, but contains a few inconsistencies, and much more importantly, there are vast areas of human endeavour for which Glosa lexicons have not been derived.  The Glosa advantage is that, in coming from the Classical roots - from which the science terminology also comes - the derivation of new terms is fairly straight-forward.


> Are there any Glosa contacts in Hong Kong?

*   I will have to get back to the authors, in England, on this.


> As for my background, I am an American who has lived

>in Hong Kong for almost 5 years. My wife is Chinese,

>originally from Beijing. We have a 6 year old son. My

>son was born in Micronesia, the island of Saipan. We

>communicate in 3 languages at home-Cantonese,

>Mandarin, and English.

*   It sounds as if your family could add another language  - for fun -

and in this respect, I suspect that you could easily start using Glosa as a "toy" language, much as some people use Pig Latin.


> I lived in Japan for 6 years and in Thailand for 2

>years. I am interested in auxiliary languages as a way

>to promote world peace and brotherhood.

*  This is a good question, and a worthwhile objective.  It is also the reason that I bought into the Auxiliary language business: I have been an unpaid promoter of Glosa since I first saw it on the drawing board, in 1977.

   However, very dark clouds hang over the "world peace and brotherhood" area, at present.  And because of this, I am putting my first priority into defining the 'post capitalist' socio-economic system; thus, I see Language Reform as just one of the bonuses to mankind that follows the demise of Exploitative Capitalism.  For this reason, I am currently putting most of my free time into looking, positively, at the responsible, frugal, co-operative world that will welcome the IAL hypothesis.

  -----


But, meanwhile, spending some time on Interlinguistics, I would ask if you think that the Seminar #1 should be in my Webpage?  Did I send the Seminar #2?

   Please try writing a couple of short sentences using Glosa.

   Placia, tenta grafo bi brevi frasa uti Glosa.


   The trick, as I see it, is to pre-digest your thinking before breaking out into words.  In English, we say "writing in Glosa" which could be rendered as ~grafo in Glosa~ [writing into Glosa] or ~grafo intra Glosa~ [writing inside Glosa], both of which would be incorrect idiomatic translations from English .. the meaning of which, in this case, is more correctly conveyed by the concept "using."


Saluta,

  Robin Gaskell

I've updated the Glosa dictionary files at

   http://www.neosplice.com/~ailanto/glosa.htm

There were only a few changes to the words themselves, some things we
talked about shortly after the last update, and I hadn't felt like doing
the whole update thing again so soon. The main change was that HEKTO
replaces CENTI for "hundred"; CENTI becomes "hundredth". This makes some
of the other words more consistent with each other...

   CENTI = hundredth
   CENTIMETRA = centimeter, centimetre

   HEKTO = hundred
   HEKTOPEDI = centipede

   MILI = thousandth
   MILIMETRA = millimeter, millimetre

Also for consistency...

   KARAKTERI = trait
   UNITA = unit

   NIMA = name
   NIMA-BILETA = label

   SUMA-ME = calculator

And the following were added...

   GE-LIMITA = exclusive

   PRANDIA = supper

   RADIA = radius

I also created a new dictionary file, the Glosa-English Basic Dictionary
(GEB), as requested by Marcel for help in his work. (Let me know if there
is anything else I can do to help.) And I added the new Glosa links to all
the cover pages. The password, as always: seleni.

Nick Hempshall grafo (00-02-24, 15:58:03): 
> Hi 
> Anyone know anything about "Tako-Glosa"? Is there anything on-line

Posi mi ski; tu puta de qo: 

(ex Richmond folia "History Behind Glosa":) 
"1986 Devised Tako-Glosa, a quick writing system, in which all Glosa 
words can be abbreviated to 1, 2 or 3 letters and can be typed on 
ordinary computerkeyboard." 

Mi pa audi de homo ra in Deutschland. Markus B"ottcher ex Braunschweig 
pa evolve u sistema; te tipo fo tako in normali puta-me. An sistema 
uti "shift"-butona, "alt"-butona e "control"-butona. 

Problema de panto tako-grafo sistema es plu verba fini. Ka-co Glosa es 
boni: id ne habe plu inflectio, e plu verba ne muta. Sed 
Richmond-verba-lista ko konfusi in verba fini (karo e kara, odori e 
odoro, e so avanti) es toxi pro panto tako-grafo-sistema! 

Tako-grafo pa es mi maxi amo libe-tem-ergo. Klu mi pa visita 
panto-Deutsch-kompeti. Mali fortuna u stude tako-grafo es fo ergo, iso 
fo de stude lingua. Posi ma fo: ka-co; qi dice, ne qi grafo; krati 
tako. 

"Tako-Glosa" sio es iso problema de auxi lingua. Idea es boni. Posi-ra 
es mega. Evolve es noo-hedo. Sed pro face utili ne existe dura-dina. - 
Markus B. habe dura-dina. Mi ne. 

Saluta. 

(I think, I know what you are thinking about:  ... [quotation of 
Richmond leaflet "History Behind Glosa"] ...  I heard about a similar 
thing in Germany.  Markus B"ottcher from Braunschweig developed a 
system to type German texts in high velocity in a normal PC.  His 
system makes use of the shift-, alt- and control-button.  A problem 
for every stenographic system are word endings.  So Glosa is quite 
suitable, because there are no inflections and words do not change.  
But the Richmond-vocabulary with its confusions in the word endings 
(karo and kara - dear; odori and odoro - smell, and so on) are poison 
for every abbreviation system! For a long time short hand has been my 
favorite hobby.  I visited even the German masterships.  Unfortunately 
the learning of a stenographic system is very hard work, as hard as 
language learning, perhaps harder, because the speaker and not the 
writer controls velocity.  Tako-Glosa will be the same problem as 
auxiliary languages.   The idea is great.  Potential is big.  
Developing it is an intelectual pleasure.  But to bring it to 
application, there is no staying power.  - Markus B. has it.  I do not. 
Greetings.)

Marcel <m.springer{at}nikocity{dot}de>

*   Hi Nick and All,

   Well, Tako-Glosa was derived by Ronald Clark as a demonstration of the
flexibility within Glosa, and as the ultimate abbreviation of the Greek
and Latin roots ... for 'telegrammatic' communication.  It is also a
ready-made shorthand for Glosa-users.


   Had more people taken an interest in the language, I am sure that Ron
would have extended the Tako-Glosa vocabulary, and demonstrated its use
more.


   No, it never made it to the Net.  We seemed to be having enough
trouble with straight Glosa.  My print of Tako-Glosa is probably filed
somewhere, but the most direct way of getting a copy, of the work done,

would be to write to Glosa Central:-

  Glosa

  <underline>P.O. Box 18, Richmond Surry TW9 2AU, U.K.


</underline>   Do You have a use for the shorthand version of Glosa, or
are you checking it out for academic reasons?  If necessary, I will write
to Wendy Ashby and ask her to send me a copy of it; afer that, it would
be a matter of my typing it in.


   As I recall, yours is the first enquiry I have seen about 
Tako-Glosa.


Saluta,


Robin Gaskell

There are now more languages used in the European Union. If you wish 
to modify the originals in some way to make them more interesting to 
German readers, please do so, - without changing the meaning, of 
course. As you become more familiar with Glosa, you may like to 
discuss with us any suggestions.

multi-media computer rather than buying seperate items and repairs 
etc. Several things are already in boxes and I cannot find the German 
version of Glosa summary. However, you will find the translations in

publish "Plu Glosa Nota" recently, we shall start again next year when 
life is more settled.

are up to PGN 83 now) or other books. Please let us know what you

again.

Poli ami saluta

(Ron Clark wrote, 2000-02-26, letter received today): 

Dear Marcel,

Thank you very much for your interesting letter..
You mention Gaskell, Bartlett, and Patterson as being responsible for 
the Web-Glosa article.
Bartlett wrote to us a long time ago, and it was he who is responsible 
for the present set-up.
We knew Robin Gaskell many years ago, when he was a teacher in 
England. We have tried to communicate with Robin several times but 
have so far received no answer. He did change his Australian address 
several times, but up to now always informed us about it immediately. 
We have been playing about with the new computer, which, of course is 
very different in many ways from our previous machines. We are very 
pleased with it, and will get on the net within the next few days we 
hope!

You speak of some errors in the Glosa list. Certainly, they must be 
dealt with immediately. You do understand I expect that in Glosa there 
are many latin and Greek suynonyms that would suffice. We do tend to 
go for brevity, however. We shall certainly fully participate in the 
Glosa Mailing List. 

Getting down now to practical details for the future.
I believe you know about the immense and world-wide publicity Glosa 
received as a result of an article about Glosa which appeared in a 
well-known educational magazine, "Language Matters" which is 
distributed to schools and colleges and large firms. It occurred right 
at the start before we had bad time to develop the Glosa idea 
properly. To be able to fully exploit all this delightful publicity we 
should have had a regular group, a lively Glosa society, meeting 
regularly. So that is now our immediate aim....to establish Glosa 
Groups everywhere. 

So Marcel, that's all for now. We would very much like to know your 
oipinion; together, hopefully, with any helpful suggestions you can 
make. We have responded in English because you asked us to. 
Thank you once again for all your heip. We sense an enthusiasm in your 
letter. 
Auf wieder-schreiben!

Ron

(-- End of correspondence --)

Subject: Re: [glosalist] Re: GEB, Glosa Dictionaries

At 19:43 22/02/2000 -0500, you wrote:
>   .....  und mein Glosa ist sehr rostig!
*   Does this mean , metaphorically, that your Glosa is rusty?

>I've updated the Glosa dictionary files at
>
>   http://www.neosplice.com/~ailanto/glosa.htm
>
*   Thank you .. obviously all of the interesting, interested, people try
to do everything all at once.  A number of us suffer the same syndrome.
    It was my day off to-day, Friday 10th, but sleep debt prevented me from
going back to see the rest of the _IT2000_ computer exhibition: my body
just said, enough.

   Possibly Sunday I will find time to look at the various Websites that
others have reccommended to me.  I will say that Lexically, you have been
the most active, and I understand this on the basis of each contributing
the part that they resonate with best. 
   In my reply to Marcel, I suggested that he might set up a satellite
Glosa site in Germany, and then encourage others to correspond across the
German/English barrier: I think he inferred that I was not maximising
opportunities for Glosa, and he is right.  If I was still as virile as I
was 20 years ago, when I first returned to Sydney from Bournemouth, I would
be more effective.
   Perhaps at this stage of my saga, the Cosmos wants me to progress in my
quest.  I am getting caught up in the larger moves that are polarising the
world into 'greedy' and 'exploited'.   I am also finding that the world's
store of spare creativity is considerably smaller than I had anticipated.
   In an attempt to encourage the formation of a group of Activists, who
would create non-violent ploys for political interventions and
demonstrations, I set up the Mailing List, "creativity": well, things did
not go as I had expected; I thought we would compile a file of activities
from which other - less creative - Activists could make selections.  It was
amazing the number of ways that people can be diverted from a seemingly
obvious central theme.

   Going on from this failure (possibly to another), I have set up another
M.L. called, "nextsystem."  Just imagine that Capitalism suffers a similar
system-collapse as that which brought down Socialism in the USSR!?  What
will replace it??  Hence I ask the question: what is the appearance of the
"Next" system, which avoids the present pitfalls, and is 'sustainable'?
   Obviously, in the present, George-Soros-type exploitative world, there
is no room for ideas that are good for Humanity, like Glosa.  But we must
be waiting in the wings, ready to appear, on cue, when the curtain raises
on the next Act.
   And, if there is to be such a Next Act, perhaps we should set about
writing it, as well as well as getting the scenery ready.  People are
decrying the present system, and they are working on pieces of the puzzle
that is our future; but, somehow, a few generalists are needed to take the
overview, and see how well the suggested pieces fit together to make up a
whole.
   Isn't it amazing: there is no catch-cry behind which progressive
thinkers might muster!  "Commun-ism" has already been used, unfortunately;
"Alternativism" is not very positive; "Sustainablism" is too much of a
mouthful; maybe something general like "Equitism" or Gaianism" might follow
the implosion of Capitalism (estimated for around 2050).

   I know that too much thinking can send one mad: but, what has happened
to the Human Spirit; why are people NOT asking the NextSystem question?
We can all see that Capitalist exploitation of the Planet has turned toxic;
and any scoolboy could do the Compound Interest sum that shows a continuing
+3% annual increase in GNP, for every economy, leads, eventually, to a call
for resources beyond the Planet's capacity.  But, the locomotive is still
hurtling towards the gorge .. even though we can surmise that the 'bridge'
might not be there, when we reach the brink - and no safety loop is being
built, or even envisaged.

MEANWHILE, BACK IN THE 'REAL' WORLD ...
   I would like to try a stanza, or two, of "The Wolf."   Try me with  some
that are difficult conceptually.
   
>There were only a few changes to the words themselves,  .....  HEKTO
>replaces CENTI for "hundred"; CENTI becomes "hundredth". This makes some

such a solution makes 'hundred' and 'hundredth' separate lexical
categories.  Likewise for ten and tenth, and thousand and thousandth!

>   MILIMETRA = millimeter, millimetre

8X-------------------------------------------------------------------

Ab u monti an nu pa veni ad u vilage*.  Tem pa gene vespera.  An pa 
atende in densi abies-silvi*.  U-la-tem an pa placidi*-ki ko kura peri 
plu fragma de plu horti, seqe ozo* de plu kordiali* animala-do*. 
Nuli-pe pa es in strata.  An pa es anxio e ko libido; an pa nikti 
inter plu domi.  U-la-tem fusili.  An pa jakula* u an kefa ana, e sti 
kursi; tem jam fusili bi fo soni.  An pa gene ge-kolpa*.  U 
sub-blanka* korpu* pa gene ge-makula in mo latu ex hema; qi hesi-ki 
kata in plu krasi* guta iso de plu perla.  Anti-co an pa pote eskapa, 
ko mega tensio-batmo*, e pa veni ad ultra monti-silvi*.  U-la an pa 
atende, audi tem momenta, e an pa audi plu voka e plu batmo* ex bi 
direkti.  An pa este anxio in panto korpu* e vide ana monti.  U monti 
pa es fo-klina, ko silvi*.  Ki ana sio es eforti.  Anti-co an pa habe 
nuli hetero elekti.  Ko anhelo pneumo, an sti skende ana fo-klina 
monti-mura; tem, sub, konfusi de plu mali-dice, de plu komanda e de 
plu lumi ex plu lanterna pa ki longi monti.  U ge-lesio* trepida* 
lupus pa skende dia semi-skoto abies-silvi*; tem u bruno hema adagio* 
flux* kata ex u-an mo latu. 

U frigi pa gene meio*. U uest urani pa habe vapori e pa sponde* fu 
nifa*.

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: Re: [glosalist] U Lupus (ANHELO, Synonyms, Dictionaries)
From: William W Patterson <ailanto{at}neosplice{dot}com>
Date: Thu, 23 Mar 2000 22:50:36 -0500

In reference to recent posts by Nick Hempshall and Marcel Springer...

Marcel> anhelo - gasp, pant  (B)

Nick> I prefer "fo-spira" or "astma"

Funny you should mention that. I just ran into "anhel*" a day or so
before your post, while translating another portion of The Wolf into
Esperanto. ASTMA would work, but brings up another issue concerning
Glosa synonyms, one that I haven't dealt with yet, and I'm glad you
brought it to my attention: Why "-ing" words in the Glosa dictionaries?
When I have time I'll make another desynonymization pass, converting
"-ing" words to infinitives as appropriate, and then we can select the
preferred synonyms for those.

ANHELO is from Latin, ASTMA from Greek. Once again we've bumped into
Glosa's Greek/Latin (and sometimes others, see below) multipersonality
nature. (I still think the creators would have been better off sticking
with one or the other and applying the grammar (one of the aspects
of Glosa which appeal to me) to that one source). (It gets even more
confusing when we bump into a Glosa word which comes from one language
but is the same as a word with a completely different meaning in the
other!) In situations like this, I often look to other IALs to see
what they've selected, thus enjoying the fruits of their research
into international words. Esperanto uses "anheli", Interlingua uses
"anhelar", etc... so I'd be inclined to choose ANHELO as the preferred
synonym.

Marcel> semi - half    (G1000; Error in "Core": (?) It must be Latin
Marcel>                 "semi" or Greek "hemi". "demi" is French.)

In the sources I used to construct the dictionaries, SEMI, HEMI, and
DEMI were all found to be Glosa words for "half". Yes, French too.
Though Glosa is based primarily on Latin and Greek, words from some
other languages have snuck in. Why I chose DEMI as the preferred
synonym, I don't recall. One problem with Glosa vocabulary is that in
many cases you will find a short Glosa word with a particular meaning,
and several Glosa words that begin with this same string of characters;
in some of those words the string has the same meaning, because they
were sourced from the same language as the short word, a language in
which that word was actually a prefix. But in other words the meaning
is not the same, because they were sourced from another language, in
which that short word either didn't exist or had a different meaning. I
probably chose DEMI as the preferred synonym because it didn't clash
with the beginning of any other words. But SEMI or HEMI might be a
better choice.

Nick>   ("Glosa 1000" against "Core".
Nick>   "Core"-words are sorted alphabetically.
Nick>   Is the synonym-problem solved - or doubled ???)

I merged Glosa 6000, the several (differing!) versions of Glosa 1000,
and words from other Glosa sources on the Net, to create the Glosa
source dictionary (GES). Glosa 1000 (in its several incarnations) is
*not*, as one might reasonably expect, a subset of Glosa 6000. Thus, the
GES is the worst of all possible worlds when it comes to synonyms, but
hopefully contains the entire Glosa word store. The GES was then pruned
in various ways to create the more basic dictionaries, the most basic
of all being the Core dictionaries (GEC and EGC). There should be no
Glosa synonyms *within* the Core dictionaries, which I hoped would
someday evolve into that fabled G2000 (in the senses of year *and*
wordcount!).

Nick> I take "kordiali" to mean "warm" emotionally, something like friendly.

Me too. But see my next post, in which I conclude that KORDIALI is
a very good choice in this context.

- Salata! - Bill

Saluta, Marcel e plu glosa-pe!

There are some minor differences between the "The Wolf" and
"Der Wolf", so some of my re-wording can be blamed on that.

ms> Ab u monti an nu pa veni ad u vilage.
bp> Kontra-latu de monti an pa veni ad vilage.

Ah, the synonym problem. Don't worry about synonyms unless they
appear *within* the Core dictionary. Particularly with final vowels.
The various dictionaries disagree a lot on final vowels.

ms> Tem pa gene vespera.

ms> An pa atende in densi abies-silvi.

ms> U-la-tem an pa placidi-ki ko kura peri plu fragma de plu horti,
ms> seqe ozo de plu kordiali animala-do.
bp> U-la-tem an pa placidi-ki ko cirkumspekt peri plu horti-fragma,
bp> seqe ozo de plu kordiali animala-do.

I like that sentence! At first I wasn't sure about the use of KORDIALI.
Is Hesse referring to warmth as in heat or as in welcomeness? And
then I realized that *both* senses are appropriate here! I do prefer
CIRCUMSPEKT to KURA, because it entails the concept of wariness. As
for HORTI-FRAGMA, that's merely a personal preference. What do the
glosalistas think?

ms> Nuli-pe pa es in strata.
bp> Nuli-pe pa in strata.

As per (much) earlier discussions here, ES is not needed when PA, NU,
or FU is used. (I'm even tempted to omit PA in that sentence.) There
was much discussion about redundancy here some time ago; Once the tense
is established, is it necessary to repeat it in the same sentence? Or
for that matter, within the same paragraph? (though that argument is a
bit weaker)

ms> An pa es anxio e ko libido; an pa nikti inter plu domi.
bp> Ko anxio e ko desira an pa skope inter plu domi.

I'm not sure about that one. Comments?

ms> U-la-tem fusili.
bp> Subito stoko.

I have a feeling that the days of U-LA-TEM are numbered. It's too long,
too many syllables, for such a simple concept. Words like that tend to
get shortened with use. SUBITO is a bit different in meaning but I like
it here. I'm not sure about FUSILI vs. STOKO here. STOKO appears to
combine a couple of similar but definitely different ideas.

More to come...

- Auf Wiederschreiben - Bill

Plu glosa-pe: saluta!

ms> Ab u monti an nu pa veni ad u vilage.
bp> Kontra-latu de monti an pa veni ad vilage.
nh> Epi ma-tele latu de monti, an vide u viki.

I find "kontra" difficult to interpret.
Is it the side you can see from your current position or the side you can't?

bp> Ah, the synonym problem.

The "two words, one idea" concept behind Glosa used to strike me as
problematic too. A theoretically optimal language would not behave
in this way. But now, I wonder if this is not a benefit, in practice.
The extra effort passively to recognise two words is compensated
for by the ability to vary the word in writing/speaking, or
alternatively to use the one that comes more easily to mind.

The problem with your method of resolving synonyms is that it
will almost always result in the selection of the Latin word, where
as I would like the Greek one! Also while all the words published in
the Glosa dictionaries must be legitimate choices in writing/speaking,
I think preference should go to words appearing in a Glosa 1000 list.

ms> Tem pa gene vespera.
nh> Id es proxi nokti.

I feel it is clearer Glosa to use an empty pronoun "id" as 'subject'
for this type of sentence.

ms> An pa atende in densi abies-silvi.

ms> U-la-tem an pa placidi-ki ko kura peri plu fragma de plu horti,
ms> seqe ozo de plu kordiali animala-do.
bp> U-la-tem an pa placidi-ki ko cirkumspekt peri plu horti-fragma,
bp> seqe ozo de plu kordiali animala-do.

"Po-co" seems better for "then".

ms> Nuli-pe pa es in strata.
bp> Nuli-pe pa in strata.

>As per (much) earlier discussions here, ES is not needed when PA, NU,
>or FU is used. (I'm even tempted to omit PA in that sentence.) There
>was much discussion about redundancy here some time ago; Once the tense
>is established, is it necessary to repeat it in the same sentence? Or
>for that matter, within the same paragraph? (though that argument is a
>bit weaker)

For me "es" is required, as I think Glosa sentences have to have a 'verb' 
equivalent.
The "pa" cannot fulfil this role. On the other hand, I think "pa" can be 
omitted if
the context (in this case, the whole story) makes the time reference clear.


ms> An pa es anxio e ko libido; an pa nikti inter plu domi.
bp> Ko anxio e ko desira an pa skope inter plu domi.
nh> An fo-skope, famina sed fobo, inter plu domi.

ms> U-la-tem fusili.
bp> Subito stoko.
nh> Il es u fusili fono.

Maxi boni nova, Marcel,
   Mi nece skope u `Record Festival` Reti-lo, te vide tu kontribu.

   Place kontinu akti so: per grafo uti Glosa tu gene id este; u ma grafo tu akti, u ma boni tu Glosa-uti gene.

 %^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%
    [posi: ~ ...; u ma ke tu grafo Glosa, u ma boni gene tu Glosa-uti.~
     alo, ~ ...; per grafo ma Glosa, tu Glosa-uti gene ma boni.~

  ### Mi vo habe plu komenta: <in E alo GL> ex plu Lista-pe, koncerne plu-ci uti.
     . Qod uti habe ma comunika valu?
    .. Qe, qo-mo maxi facili don u semani?
   ... E qe, mo de plu-ci uti habe ma poeti?
  .... Qod uti tu kogita habe ma kongru ko plu regula de Glosa uti?
     : Pluso, don (plu) alterno mode de expresi plu-ci idea.
 %^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%^%

   Mi nece duce Marcel bi, per adi u mero de kontu kodi a mi Reti-pagina, e per registra mi Reti-lo ko plu Cerka-Dyna-me.  Pre u-ci, il es plura muta mi nece face ad u pagina:
 . muta u Post-Kodi, pro plu autori-pe, ad id neo valu, de TW9 1WD,
 . adi u nexu a Marcel URL,
 . adi u kontu-ra ad u loka,
 . e adi Seminar #2.

   Plu autori-pe habe u neo Posta-Kodi, sed il es nuli muta a plu hetero detaila.  Tu pote grafo a mu to:-
      Ronald Clark & Wendy Ashby
      GLOSA
      PO Box 18
      Richmond
      Surry  TW9 1WD
      England

   Pluso, mu pa merca u neo puta-me, habe pasa-in mu paleo modela.  In u futura, tosto, mi spe, mu skema de re-jugo un Inter-Reti.

   Marcel, qod numera de plu Reti-pe; qi visita tu Reti-lo, dice-qestio de ma info, alo de jugo u Glosa-uti grega?  A qo-numera de plu-ci visita-pe tu posta komunika in alo Glosa alo Deutschland-lingua?

   Marcel, mi vo qestio tu koncerne u " .. verba-lista du ne sati", e vo habe tu grafo ma de id.  U-ci pa kausa dificili pro tu, tem kom-pila tu Reti-lo.  Place, grafo a na, de plu-ci problema, so na pote tenta solve mu, ko tu.
 
   Qod mero de ~ ... Traduce de "Glosa Basic Reference" in Deutsch~ pa kausa plu problem pro tu,
  simpli un uti de u pusi ge-praxi lingua,
  u qantita de un ergo, 
  plu no-kongru contenta de u lista,
  alo plu dificili ko plu koncepa de face u verbi-lista dictionari?

   Alo, qe, tu habe plu problema, de habe akorda, ko plu idea ge-expresi intra u "Basic Reference"?  Mi spe, ke tu ne traduce in Deutsch, u dice-ra, "Glosa has no grammar".  E mi spe; tu pa detekti u hetero mode de dice id, posi ke .. Glosa habe nuli flexi te muta u semani de plu verbi, e, so, Glosa habe nuli muta a plu verbi pro plu raisona de gramatika.  

<Eng>

Thank you for your comments. It is great to translate a few lines and 
then discuss it in glosalist.  It helps me learning.  It is even 
better for Glosa when we come from different native languages.  A 
discussion on that level produces not only translations but 
literature!  It does not matter, if we make only 13 lines per month.  
We will not fill a library with Glosa-literature, but it is a start of 
it!  Maybe we can continue this. 

Three small things:

  Nick wrote:
  > Also "meio" means less/lessen.
Right.  Sorry.  Mistake in my list.  But in the translation it is used 
the right way. 

  > "kordiali" ... emotion not temperature
I have been afraid of that already (cf. Latin cor, cordis n. - heart). 
Here I used the "Core"-dictionary too strictly.  A few lines earlier 
in the text Hesse told us that a barn means no place of friendlyness 
to the wolf.  It is the place of bloody orgys and massacre.  "Warm" 
means full of living beings, animals to kill and to eat.  Nick 
convinced me of "meso-termo". 

  > subito / u-la-tem / po-co 
I have to learn, that "po-co" is often better than "u-la-tem". 
"subito" (suddenly, abruptly; pl"otzlich) goes in the direction of 
"surprisingly".  Nobody in the street.  Then a shot. - The poet refused 
to mention, that that is a surprise.  Hesse used "da" (then, there), a 
short word, only one syllable.  And it sounds similar to a shot. 
Childrens playing war imitate gunshots with "da".  "U-la-tem" does not 
sound like a shot.  "subito" does not either.  Latin "tum" would be 
great, but it is not a Glosa word, or is it?

24 Mar 2000 09:09:46 PST, Nick Hempshall...

> The problem with your method of resolving synonyms is that it
> will almost always result in the selection of the Latin word, where
> as I would like the Greek one! Also while all the words published in
> the Glosa dictionaries must be legitimate choices in writing/speaking,
> I think preference should go to words appearing in a Glosa 1000 list.

(Based on my experiences with Glosa vocabularies, I wouldn't be at all
surprised to find ANHELO and ASTMA represented equally!)

I didn't mean to imply that this was my only method, or even a primary
method. In fact, it's one of the methods of last resort! First I look
within the dictionary, comparing the synonyms with other Glosa words.
Are any of the synonyms found to be parts of other words? If yes, and
the meaning is similar... that's an argument in favor of preferential
status. If yes, but the meaning is very different... then that's an
argument against preferential status.

You are correct, comparison with other IALs would probably result in
increasing Latinization of Glosa. From the point of view of acceptance
of an international auxiliary language, that's probably a good thing.
Latin has had a bigger influence than Greek on languages worldwide, so,
on average, greater Latinization will mean greater accessibility to the
public.

Of course, that aspect of ease-of-learning (at-sight-comprehension and
true-friendliness) is a short-term consideration. In the long-term, word
source and initial recognizability are irrelevant. I kind of prefer Greek
words in Glosa too, *because* they are less familiar (more unusual) and
thus seem to work more smoothly with Glosa's grammar, at least for this
Germanic/Romance user!

> ms> Tem pa gene vespera.
> nh> Id es proxi nokti.
> 
> I feel it is clearer Glosa to use an empty pronoun "id" as 'subject'
> for this type of sentence.

I must disagree! What is the "it" that we're talking about, to what is
"it" referring? That "it" is characteristic of certain languages, but
isn't necessary or even usually explicable, except by reference to some
grammatical rule that simply states that "this is what we do". I like
Marcel's version, a nonambiguous subject/verb/object, stating that the
"time became evening(time)".

> ms> Nuli-pe pa es in strata.
> bp> Nuli-pe pa in strata. *or* Nuli-pe in strata.
>
> For me "es" is required, as I think Glosa sentences have to have a 'verb' 
> equivalent. The "pa" cannot fulfil this role. On the other hand, I think
> "pa" can be omitted if the context (in this case, the whole story) makes
> the time reference clear.

*Can* "pa" fufill this role? What *is* the role of "es"? Do Glosa sentences
have to have a verb? If so, should they? So many questions! Fair warning:
when it comes to Glosa, I'm a minimalist.

- Later - Bill

Bill pa grafo
>
>I didn't mean to imply that this was my only method, or even a primary
>method. In fact, it's one of the methods of last resort! First I look
>within the dictionary, comparing the synonyms with other Glosa words.
>Are any of the synonyms found to be parts of other words? If yes, and
>the meaning is similar... that's an argument in favor of preferential
>status. If yes, but the meaning is very different... then that's an
>argument against preferential status.
>

I'm not sure that we should expect Glosa words to be made up of meaningful 
sub-elements. Of course they are to some extent because of etymological 
relationships in the source languages, but shouldn't the words be treated as 
unanalysable within the language itself. (Of course, this doesn't apply to 
Glosa own compound words).

>
>You are correct, comparison with other IALs would probably result in
>increasing Latinization of Glosa. From the point of view of acceptance
>of an international auxiliary language, that's probably a good thing.
>Latin has had a bigger influence than Greek on languages worldwide, so,
>on average, greater Latinization will mean greater accessibility to the
>public.
>

Perhaps this region of the IAL spectrum is already too over-crowded.

>
> > ms> Tem pa gene vespera.
> > nh> Id es proxi nokti.
> >
> > I feel it is clearer Glosa to use an empty pronoun "id" as 'subject'
> > for this type of sentence.
>
>I must disagree! What is the "it" that we're talking about, to what is
>"it" referring? That "it" is characteristic of certain languages, but
>isn't necessary or even usually explicable, except by reference to some
>grammatical rule that simply states that "this is what we do". I like
>Marcel's version, a nonambiguous subject/verb/object, stating that the
>"time became evening(time)".
>

As I say the "id" is an empty pronoun in my sentence, so it doesn't refer to 
anything. It is just filling the 'slot' in the syntactic structure. I'm not 
saying that it is a 'logical' or 'natural' requirement in a language, but as 
the 'slot' in the syntactic structure is what gives specific 'meaning' to 
the words in Glosa, perhaps it is not a bad idea to have a mandatory 
subject.

For me "(TEM) time/duration cannot become evening", though maybe it can be 
done with HORO. ~Horo pa gene vespera.~


> > ms> Nuli-pe pa es in strata.
> > bp> Nuli-pe pa in strata. *or* Nuli-pe in strata.
> >
> > For me "es" is required, as I think Glosa sentences have to have a 
>'verb'
> > equivalent. The "pa" cannot fulfil this role. On the other hand, I think
> > "pa" can be omitted if the context (in this case, the whole story) makes
> > the time reference clear.
>
>*Can* "pa" fufill this role? What *is* the role of "es"? Do Glosa sentences 
>have to have a verb? If so, should they?

I think they do have to have a verb to be a Glosa sentence.
Like the 'id' question, I don't think that it is a 'logical' or 'natural' 
requirement in a language, just the way Glosa is at this point in its 
evolution.

My syntax based view of ~Nuli-pe pa in strata~
No-one in-streeted. => No-one entered the street.

So the role of "es" is to stop that interpretation.

A kron,

Nick

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: Re: [glosalist] Words & Grammar
From: Charles <catty{at}pacificnet{dot}net>
Date: Sun, 26 Mar 2000 19:07:27 -0800

Been a while since I spouted off on this list,
but how could I desist longer, with all this
interesting talk about vocabulary and syntax ..

Nick Hempshall wrote, in part:

> My syntax based view of ~Nuli-pe pa in strata~
> No-one in-streeted. => No-one entered the street.
> 
> So the role of "es" is to stop that interpretation.

Glosa has the least morphology, the most English syntax,
and the highest proportion of Greek, of all its serious
IAL/auxlang competitors. Its grammar is the easiest
to teach, simply by saying "forget school grammar,
it's like this" and showing a few examples. Still, there
must be a rational pattern to it as I think Nick explains
in a fresh and convincing manner. My own attempts to
write parser programs have led me to the following:

English and Glosa both follow a simple and flexible pattern of
syntax in which "little words" precede and "big words" follow.
This applies to noun and verb phrases, and outside of literature,
that is *all* that needs specifying. So, one expects to see
something like prepositions and determiners initiating noun phrases,
and particles/auxiliaries initiating verb phrases. Easy as pie
to parse, though the connection between phrases is "semantic"
and loose. That's just the way language is, outside of a classroom.

Glosa has some problems though, in my honest opinion, and
requires a lot more work before it can be used in the real world.

Mi sio grafo: "per ma-grafo Glosa, tu Glosa-uti ma-boni".

De "pre u-ci" -

"Pre" is a time word, so what follows it has to be
a time or an event, this gives "u-ci" the meaning
the latter event, ie the registration as opposed
to the code addition, or following Marcel's example.
If you meant before "all the events I just mentioned",
then, "po-co" would be what I would suggest.

De "Mi nece duce Marcel bi" -

I guess you intended "seqe" here.
Marcel bi = Marcel the 2nd :-)
What do you think of "bi-mode"?
Does "nece" indicate that you are being compelled
to do so, as opposed to "volu", wishing to do so,
or "debi", felling that it would be good to do so?

Poli ami saluta,

Nick

Karo Nick, 

  Tu pa grafo:
  > ms > ... hesi-ki kata ... iso de plu perla. 
  > nh > hesi: English version has "steady" = NO-MUTA 
  > nh > iso de: HOMO (like) 
Ko u-ci komplika ra mi pa volu traduce "herabrieselte": 
   "herab"    = kata  (down) 
   "rieseln"  = ???   (purl, ripple, trickle) 
Qe tu habe proposi? 
Penite, mi pa no-memo grafo u "pa". 
   (With this complicated structure I wanted to paraphrase 
   "herabrieselte". ... Do you have a proposal?  Sorry, I forgot the 
   "pa".) 

  Tu pa grafo: 
  > konfusi ... pa ki longi monti. 
  > nh > longi: PERI - English version has "skirted". 
Mi Glosa frase ne es harmoni, sed id mimi u Deutsch frase. U Deutsch 
stude-infanti sio gene in turba ko-co. U poeti merito Nobel-preci 
ko-co! 
   (My Glosa sentence is not consistent, but it imitates the German. 
   A German pupil would come into trouble with such in an essay, but 
   the poet gains a Nobel price.) 
English try:
   Confusion ... skirted ALONG (= entlangziehen = longi ki) the 
   mountain. 
Logically better: 
   Confusion ... skirted along THE WAY UP the mountain 
   (but there is no WAY to be seen because of the snow?).

From: Robin Gaskell <rgaskell{at}zeta{dot}org{dot}au>

At 09:18 20/03/2000 PST, Nick Hemshell wrote:

 .. Following Marcel Springer's  translation ..

>>Vocabulary

>>==========

>>   (Words, not taken from the "Core"-dictionary.

>>   Sources: (B) - Base Dictionary, (G1000) - Glosa 1000)

>>abies      - fir tree    (B)

>>libido     - desire      (B)

>>nikti      - blink       (B)

>>sti        - switch on   (B)

>>guta       - drop        (B)

>>iso .. de  - like        (G1000, B)

>>fo-klina   - steep       (B)

>>anhelo     - gasp, pant  (B)

>

>I prefer "fo-spira" or "astma"

>

*  Of these three, I prefer the construction, because it has the drama of ~fo-~, and does not need to extend the lexicon for this little-used concept.

   Re ~iso ... de~, I have learnt this as "as ... as"

coming across as "AS ... OF/AS/THAN" - making free use of ~de~ as the multifunction preposition.

EG ~An es iso mega de u domi.~  [He is as big as a house.]


>>lanterna   - lantern     (B)

>>semi       - half        (G1000; Error in "Core": (?) It must be Latin

>>                           "semi" or Greek "hemi". "demi" is French.)

>>

*   I noted that Bill Patterson in a later post covers this too (discovered while doing a Ctrl+F "find").

    The authors very generously give all three in the G-->E section of Glosa 6000, so it could be a case of take-your-pick.  But:-

  . other concepts in the same lexical space could be seen as possibly causing confusion (demo [people], sema [sign], haemi [blood]),

  . one could/should be chosen for a First Dictionary - without synonyms,

  . The Latin dictionary has a number of uses of both ~semi-~ and ~demi-~,

  . the "D" of 'deuce', `due`, "deux", might favour ~demi~ = in two,

  . SEMI has come to mean "in part", and thus might infer an approximation,

  . with poetry, when dealing with an educated readership, all synonyms should be available for purposes of assonance, alternatively, for the avoidance of alliteration, or simply to follow the muse.


>>

>>Glosa 1000-words

>>================

>>   ("Glosa 1000" against "Core".

>>   "Core"-words are sorted alphabetically.

>>   Is the synonym-problem solved - or doubled ???)

>>

*   As Nick points out the first column are generally better known, being from the more frequently circulated Glosa 1000 lists, but I would also add that glosa vocab has undegone a very rpid, artificially induced process of linguistic evolution.  It is with a memory of this developmental saga that I see most of the words in the first list as having been through a 'polishing' process through use, which has resulted in producing words with more or less optimal rhythm, consonant mix, and length.  Also, after the authors declared the terminal vowels to be 'deregulated' (~1989) there was some experimentation with these, and, subsequently, when the 1992 _Glosa 6000_ came out, some had been changed, but it was generally agreed that a set terminal vowel made life easier for everyone.

   ~flu~ lost an additional terminal "E", and ~mei~ was once "MEIO'.


>>lento       - adagio    (slow)

>>animali     - animala   (animal)

>>gradu       - batmo     (step)

>>leuko       - blanka    (white)

>>flu         - flux      (flow)

>>paki        - krasi     (thick) (krasi - thick, grasi - fat ?)

*  ~grosi~ [bulky] G6k


>>bali        - jakula    (cast, throw)

*  ~bali [(to) ball) flows, while ~jakula~ has the awkward "J-K" combination.


>>bate        - kolpa     (hit)

*  ~bate~ flows off the tongue, while ~kolpe has two hard sounds, "K" & "P".


>>meso-termo  - kordiali  (warm)

*  This is a case of the Word-Translation Dictionary not allowing for distinctions between objective and metaphorical usage of the one concept:

  ~meso-termo~ is a physical "middle-heat", while ~kordiale~ is a metaphorical 'heat' from the "heart".


>>soma        - korpu     (body)

>>vulne       - lesio     (wound)

>>mei         - meio      (more)

*  This could be a genuine mistake.  ~ma~ and ~mei~ are unfortunately very close in sound, but opposite in meaning: ~ma~ [more] is from ~major~ [greater]; ~mei~ [less] is from ~meio~ [lessen] ... //inflection in Glosa//?


>>nivi        - nifa      (snow)

>>odoro       - ozo       (smell)

>>no-soni     - placidi   (quiet, still)

*  Another case of objective vs metaphorical use: ~no-soni~ [no sound]; ~placidi~ [calm(ness)] seems related more to the Latin word ``placito`` [to please].  The Latin dictionary gives -

    placidus  gentle, quiet, calm, peaceful, placid, kind, mild.


>>silva       - silvi     (forest, wood)

>>promise     - sponde    (promise)

>>tremulo     - trepida   (shake, tremble)

>>viki        - vilage    (village)

>>

*   ~Mu pa habita u viki intra u silvi.~ [They lived in a village in the woods.]  Both ~viki~ and ~vilage~ are in G6k; but, remember the rules of pronunciation go against the latter, because the "G" is hard. 

  IE, ~vilage~ --> vEE-lARgAY, using the Gaskell system of phonics.  Compare this with ~viki~ --> vEEkEE.

    The G6k has   silvi wood,forest.  Does the "I" sound, and 'feel', better, or have I just conditioned myself to conform with the decision from Richmond, Surry? 


>I would use the first column (Glosa 1000) words as more generally known.

>

*   Me too, for the reasons given.  Twenty years can be a long time in the pressure-cooker world of Planned Language evolution and development.

 

>Also -

>   .....

>I take "kordiali" to mean "warm" emotionally, something like friendly.

>

>Also "meio" means less/lessen.

>

*   I wish to add that Glosa is not supposed to be a coldly lexical language, but that the shapes and sounds of the words are also intended to embody their meaning, and feeling.

    This is not actually written down in any of Glosa's promotional literature, but it is something I have intuited: both from observing the language, from the sidelines, as it unfolded; and from developing the taste for the language, by rolling it around in my mouth.


Salutas,

   Robin

At 13:02 25/03/2000 +0100, Marcel grafo:
>Thank you for your comments. It is great to translate a few lines and 
>then discuss it in glosalist.  It helps me learning.  It is even

*
*   Agreed, the multicultural discussion is very fruitful, however, for my
purposes, an English-language version of the poem is probably necessary, to
enable me to maximise my contribution to the discussion.

>  A 
>discussion on that level produces not only translations but 
>literature!  It does not matter, if we make only 13 lines per month.  
>We will not fill a library with Glosa-literature, but it is a start of 
>it!  Maybe we can continue this.
*
*  Quite so, however I submit the suggestion that some of the discussion
about the poem also be conducted also in Glosa; we are among friends, here,
and any variations will be accepted in the spirit in which they are
uttered.   
   When Marcel and I exchange notes, we use Glosa exclusively, this being
for both our benefits.

>Three small things:
>
>  Nick wrote:
>  > Also "meio" means less/lessen.
>Right.  Sorry.  Mistake in my list.  But in the translation it is used 
>the right way. 
>
*   The four-letter form was the Glosa original, but then the authors moved
to drop the "O" to replace ~meio~ with ~mei~; however, through some
mismatching in my head, this could have resulted in the two forms
persisting - with slightly different meanings, viz, mei = less, and meio =
lessen.

>  > "kordiali" ... emotion not temperature
>I have been afraid of that already (cf. Latin cor, cordis n. - heart). 
>Here I used the "Core"-dictionary too strictly.  A few lines earlier 
>in the text Hesse told us that a barn means no place of friendlyness 
>to the wolf.  It is the place of bloody orgys and massacre.  "Warm" 
>means full of living beings, animals to kill and to eat.  Nick 
>convinced me of "meso-termo". 
>
*  A further demonstration that 'context' is possibly more important than
the actual words we are given to work with.

>  > subito / u-la-tem / po-co 
>I have to learn, that "po-co" is often better than "u-la-tem". 
>"subito" (suddenly, abruptly; pl"otzlich) goes in the direction of 
>"surprisingly".  Nobody in the street.  Then a shot. - The poet refused 
>to mention, that that is a surprise.  Hesse used "da" (then, there), a 
>short word, only one syllable.  And it sounds similar to a shot. 
>Childrens playing war imitate gunshots with "da".  "U-la-tem" does not 
>sound like a shot.  "subito" does not either.  Latin "tum" would be 
>great, but it is not a Glosa word, or is it? 
>
*   The shortage of such expletives, explosives and onomatopoea, as *DA*,
in Glosa could be a fault.
    In 'Old Glosa', ~poi~ [then] gave us the short sharp change in timing.
O.G. also featured ~posto~ [after;afterwards], but this was shortened to
~post~ and ~po~ (~po-~), the abbreviated form; ~poi~ [then] was lost in the
shuffle.
    For literary (and poetic) reasons there might be a case for reviving
the archaic form, ~poi~, in the larger Glosa lexicon.
    ~po-co~ is a different kind of "then": it represents a reflective,
philosophical change of pace, IE
   PO = after
   CO = all that I have said
.: PO-CO = after all that I have said (='and now consider this')

   The closest to ^tum^ is ~tumulu~ [tumult], possibly being a series of
short sharp shouts.

Saluta,
  Robin

much, much better, in the long run. 
  It is our job to make this happen, and to do it sooner rather than later.

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: Re: [glosalist] Words & Grammar
From: Robin Gaskell <rgaskell{at}zeta{dot}org{dot}au>
Date: Fri, 31 Mar 2000 23:49:33 +1000

At 10:35 26/03/2000 -0500, Bill wrote:
>24 Mar 2000 09:09:46 PST, Nick Hempshall...
>   .....
>
>   .....   I kind of prefer Greek
>words in Glosa too, *because* they are less familiar (more unusual) and
>thus seem to work more smoothly with Glosa's grammar, at least for this
>Germanic/Romance user!
>
*   There is also the thought that Greek word elements are more abstract,
and thus more flexible,than the Latin, which are often more concrete in
their conceptualisation.

>> ms> Tem pa gene vespera.
>> nh> Id es proxi nokti.
>> 
>> I feel it is clearer Glosa to use an empty pronoun "id" as 'subject'
>> for this type of sentence.
>
>I must disagree! What is the "it" that we're talking about, to what is
>"it" referring? That "it" is characteristic of certain languages, but
>isn't necessary or even usually explicable, except by reference to some
>grammatical rule that simply states that "this is what we do". I like
>Marcel's version, a nonambiguous subject/verb/object, stating that the
>"time became evening(time)".
>
*   "it" is the 'day'.  So, we could say that:-  Di pa gene vespera.

    But when using a word like TEM at the start of a sentence, it is easy
to misread its use, into thinking of it adverbially.  Here the 'noun
marker', U, comes in very handy: there is not a milisecond of uncertainty
in the mind of the reader, we are dealing with the concept of "time".
 IE:  U tem pa gene vespera.
 
>> ms> Nuli-pe pa es in strata.
>> bp> Nuli-pe pa in strata. *or* Nuli-pe in strata.
>>
>> For me "es" is required, as I think Glosa sentences have to have a
>>'verb' equivalent. The "pa" cannot fulfil this role. On the other hand,
>>I think "pa" can be omitted if the context (in this case, the whole
>>story) makes the time reference clear.
>
*   The full form is probably,  ~Nuli-pe pa es in u strata.~
    This could be minimalised to  ~Nuli-pe es in strata~
       if we know the time-frame is 'past', and we elide the ~u~.

    Alternatively, there is is also the other empty pronoun, IL [=there].
    Using the full form, we could have  ~Il pa es nuli-pe in u strata.~
    With elipsis, this could become  ~Es nuli-pe in strata.~ 

>*Can* "pa" fufill this role? What *is* the role of "es"? Do Glosa
>sentences have to have a verb? If so, should they? So many questions!
>Fair warning: when it comes to Glosa, I'm a minimalist.
>- Later - Bill
>
*  I believe that, for those who need regularity in their lives, the verb
in sentence answer is YES.
   I feel the idea of using the particle (pa) instead of the verb (es) to
tell us about the 'action' does not work.  The English equivalent might be
in turning "He entered the room." into "He did into the room."
   Bill, there is some difference in our approach to reductionism: While
you are a minimalist, I am an elipsist.

   Yet, for me, the ultimate judges of grammar are the eye and the ear:
after the initial creative effort of writing, does the sentence, when read
aloud, bring back to mind the original meaning that you intended;
does casually running the eye over the written words instantly 'refresh the
original idea, in your consciousness?  

Saluta,
  Robin
