To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: Re: [glosalist] Re: dictionary
From: Charles <catty{at}pacificnet{dot}net>
Date: Thu, 31 Aug 2000 13:09:18 -0700


> > LECT is one of the important crypto-roots:
> > "select, collect, delect, elect ...". Each of those has further
> > sets of derivatives. It's designed deeply into the system.
> 
> I think these root families are very interesting, but I don't see how the
> meanings of the words are related in present day Glosa. They feel like they
> represent distinct "concepts" to me.

In a sense they are distinct concepts. The average person cannot
predict that "sit/stand + again/back" would mean "stay/remain".
Yet that is how Latin and Glosa have chosen: RESID and RESTA.
I would have expected "MANA = stay" for Glosa, but instead
"MANA = morning". So it is clear that Glosa accepts the Latin
word building system of a prefixed vague adverb with a root:
EMANAte, IMANE=in+mana, PERMANEnt. 

But in a deeper sense there is intuitive "natural" logic
in this system. From a small number of basic verb roots ("trunks"),
the first branches will tend to follow the lines of multiplicity
or repetition or unification or metaphorical motion toward/away.
Those are the RE- KO- etc directional prefixes, and Greek uses
them too, and so do all the "international words" ... no escape!

There were very similar processes in the Amerindian languages.
I urge skeptics to closely examine the combined Glosa vocabulary.
What I at first thought was dispensable in the Glosa-6000 words
turns out to be the most essential.

> A parallel English example would be "meeting eating" or "eating meeting".
> Only a larger context would explain what was intended.

But "larger context" is never a satifactory solution in any
designed language. Even a pidgin quickly evolves an idiom
to express frequent concepts. [I reformat examples below.]

> ~Kani vora.~                  Dog(s) is/are/were/will be eating.

Is that "dog eats" or "dog's food" or "dog voraciousness"?
Glosa has no morphological part-of-speech distinctions,
so "kani vora" is a valid (but vague) noun phrase.
Thus it confuses possessives, gerunds, verbs, whatever.
I would not accept your sentence as valid except as
a "telegraphed" form of "u kani pa/nu vora".

> ~Vora kani ne es mi more.~    Eating dogs is not my pratice.
>                               Dog eating is not my practice.

Vora kani es u menace.          Voracious dogs are a menace.

> ~Kani, qi vora, es de mi.~    The dog(s), which is/are eating, belong(s) to me.
>                               The eating dogs belong to me.

That is clear but too clumsy for common use. Glosa needs
both a clear possesive and a present participle.

> ~Galina ne es boni kaso kani vora~    Chicken isn't good as a dog meal.
> (~vora~ = eat = eating = a meal)

That could also mean "chicken isn't the average dog's eating".
I think these examples have helped prove the point ...

> "dog's food"     ~kani vora-ma~  ~kani sito~

> "dog voraciousness"   ~kani fo-vora-volu~   ~kani fo-famina~  ~kani edace~

Yes, adding either -MA or FO- does make it clear.

> The 'particles' are only required if you want to be specific and context
> doesn't make it clear.

Right, but that is maybe half of the time; people like to elide
where possible, but need a convenient idiom to specify when
needed. That can be via morphology or syntax or both.

> > Vora kani es u menace.          Voracious dogs are a menace.
> 
> I don't think ~vora~ can be understood as 'voracious'.
> 'Voracious' = 'very hungry' = ~fo-famina~

I was thinking more like "biting dogs", fixated as I was on
participles. Since then, I have found -NT- embedded in so many
Glosa roots, I feel free to use that productively. Now it's
the GE- that seems redundant ...

> > > ~Galina ne es boni kaso kani vora~    Chicken isn't good as a dog meal.
> > > (~vora~ = eat = eating = a meal)
> >
> > That could also mean "chicken isn't the average dog's eating".
> 
> ~medio~ is average as far as I know.
> How do go you get ~boni kaso~ = average?

Any run of morphologically undistinguished roots is ambiguous; this
could be "boni caso kani" + "vora", or "boni caso" + "kani vora",
or ... This is sometimes called an attachment ambiguity.

> Another possibility would be to use ~kani~ as an imperative verb -
> ~Kani vora!~     Dog the meal!  (=Eat the meal like a dog would do!)

Or more idiomatically, "Pig out! Wolf it down!" ...

> > I was thinking more like "biting dogs", fixated as I was on

And it's not that I hate dogs, really ...

> ~Kani, qi morda, es u menace.~       Biting dogs are a menace.   (ie dogs that bite)

According to the Authorities (originally Hogben),
it should be "kani; qi ..." but such abuse of a
semicolon is too foolish to even discuss.

> ~Morda kani es u menace.~    Biting dogs is a menace. (ie people that bite dogs)

Infinitive: MORDARE kani es ...

> ~Morda ex kani es u menace.~   Biting dogs are a menace.   (ie dogs that bite)

Active participle: MORDANTE kani ...

Of course, this would spoil Glosa's ability to claim that it has no grammar
or at least no morphology. But I think the authors A&C never really intended
it as a true pidgin-creole, but rather as a semi-naive relexing of English.
Hogben meant something different altogether, but his ideas were just
the outline of a very strange project, one that appealed strongly to me
30 years ago, and seems quite silly now; A&C improved it greatly.

> ~Morda de kani es u menace.~   Biting dogs is a menace.   (ie people that bite dogs)

I think the more international usage is "Morda A/AD ..."

> > > > > ~Galina ne es boni kaso kani vora~    Chicken isn't good as a dog meal.
> > > > > (~vora~ = eat = eating = a meal)

> > Any run of morphologically undistinguished roots is ambiguous;

> True. I was attempting to use ~kaso~ prepositionally here, meaning "in the
> case of". Would perhaps ~Galina ne es boni de kani vora~  have been clearer?

Yes, anything that breaks up a long noun phrase will help.
I would try "Galina ne es boni PRO ...".

> > But "mangia" (munch) sounds best, though spelled oddly ...
> 
> This would have a "hard" G as in Get?

More likely the authors took MANGIARE from Italian.
MANG- looks like "mango". Maybe the Glosa phonology
simply does not support (should not allow) MANGIA.
Or, my proposal to use J could be invoked: MANJA.
Then there's a conflict with MANIA unless J is
always pronounced as soft-G, as it *should* be.

Glosa (Ron Clark) chose to eliminate doubled letters
and use K for hard-C. Such in-my-opinion misguided
phoneticization generates many problems like these.
I suppose the answer is to eliminate all troublesome
roots like MANGIA, because others can always be found
that *will* fit his procrustean orthography.

> And I can't forbear adding:  German learners of Ido are explicitly

> letters are entirely interchangeable to them, presumably.
> 
> (Again, that is fine, again I'm not knocking the Germans; but why
> waste the letter in Glosa, an invented language in which the
> matter was not historically determined, but was at the entire
> option of the inventor?  Is it too late to make a needed
> change?  Whence cometh, exactly, the necessity for the German J
> in Glosa?)

Vulgar/Ecclesiatical Latin and the Romance languages changed
consonantal U/I into V/J, or something like that, and it seems
like a good idea to me. But we still have the C/K and G/J
"problems" in Glosa. There isn't any other way of doing soft-G,
and the -ia combination is used instead of J as originally stated.
So it is tempting to pronounce J as soft-G and say MANJA.

But I prefer the Occidental solution of using the same
old I-before-E rules we all know since childhood ...
eliminating K altogether. What is the most international
(European) method? Nobody uses K except some very few
interlinguists! Glosa is mired in a naive phoneticism.

Some of the things you say Catty really bug me. This is one
of 'em. First the Occidental solution isn't really a solution at
all. It is problem that gets set aside far too often. Jespersen
dealt with it the same way Rosenberger and even Pirro dealt
with it... that is they represented the sound as "fonetik"-ly as
possible. And there were more than a few, you can check the
Auxilingua Project Pages and get a clue about the different
language projects that did the same. It is not naive to use
K instead of a C with double sounds. It is, however, naive
to say that Occidental is the solution. If Occidental is the
solution then practice Occidental. Glosa is good enough
for me with its Ks and I see no problem in it.

Since,
Jay B.

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: [glosalist] other IALs of similar analytic type
From: Charles <catty{at}pacificnet{dot}net>
Date: Tue, 05 Sep 2000 20:50:14 -0700


I am re-reading some of the early Kosmoglott magazines,
edited by Edgar De Wahl, deviser of Occidental/Interlingue.
In those days the IAL options were mainly Espo-Ido,
Peano's Interlingua, and Occidental in-between. In my
previous reading I skipped anything not concerning OCC,
but there were many articles by Peano and others about
(and/or written in) their own language projects.
This time I'm reading them all ... except Esperanto,
which I cannot penetrate due to its mangled roots.

Besides Interlingua's great resemblance to Glosa,
as remarked by somebody on this list earlier, I find
some other interesting foreshadowings of Interglossa/Glosa.
These were well-received and never criticized by OCC-ists;
I think EDW would be more "analytical" today than he felt
was possible then, due to prevalence of Latin in schools.

Most of this is rather easy to understand at first sight,
but some details are difficult. The most radical of the
writers is Nik Yucmanof of Petropol, in his all-lower-case
(proletarian?) language/notation "Etem". Sometimes he revues
other langs of similar type, one of which is called "Glott"
and has some interesting parallels with Glosa. (So here I'm
trying to revue a revue of a lang in a lang in a lang!)

: "glott" usu alfabet anglo-latin

: gramatik de "glott" es analitic.
: numer es indikat per numerativ (du soldat)
: aut per artikul: definit "la" (sing.), "les" (pl.),
: indefinit "un" (sing.), "plures" (pl.);
: deklin es fakat per "preposision":
: "de la patre", "ad la matre"", ...;

(More stuff too similar to Glosa deleted)

: adverbi et adjektiv ne es diferensiat;
: verb es interesant: radik de id es ekstrakt
: eks parol intereuropean ko "-or, -iv, -ur, ...",
: ergo: "amat, skript, decis, evolut ...";

(In other words, verbs are taken from the Latin
perfective/supine as is usual in English. Good idea!)

: sintakt es preferet logikal, simil a tip angl.
: stil es mult klar.

"Still"? Hmph.

: parol-formasion es simpl: sufiks et prefiks
: korespond a id de "occidental"

Which in turn corresponds to Espo-Ido.
In those days nobody dared present a project
lacking a credible system for word-derivation.

: selekt de leksik es tal: radik et parol,
: difus in omni lingu european, es akseptat
...
: in mank de parol inter-european, on selekt radik,
: komun a du famili lingual: "automne" (roman et angl),
: "fenestre" (germano-roman), "columbe" (romano-slav)

That's a refreshingly simple and effective algorithm.

This all confirms the "all eurolangs are dialects of
a single international lang" hypothesis. Nothing is
really new about Glosa, and previous analytic projects
have been better in some important ways.

Odd, that all these East-European language designers have
bypassed Greek for Latin roots, whereas Hogben and A&C ...

On Tue, 5 Sep 2000, Charles wrote (end):

> Odd, that all these East-European language designers have
> bypassed Greek for Latin roots, whereas Hogben and A&C ...

    That does bring up one thing which I think has been somewhat
questionable all along about the design of both Interglossa and Glosa
going back to Hogben himself, namely, the assumption that because many
people use words containing Greek roots, they somehow know the meaning
of those roots as if they were lexical atoms.  Elsewhere I have termed
this the Hogben Fallacy.  These days, I suspect that even scientists or
biological taxonomists consult dictionaries or even classical scholars
to help with the coining of new terms or Linnaean-type names.  I have
enough of a smattering of classical education that I can sometimes
recognize the roots in new coinings, but I suspect that most people
can't.  As best I recall without digging out my photocopy, Frater,
which was devised by a Vietnamese and published in Saigon, was rather
Glosa-like but leaned more to Latin roots (although with its
deliberately restricted phonology, there was a bit of mangling).

Subject: [glosalist] The Hogben Fallacy (was - other IALs of similar analytic type)
From: "Nick Hempshall" <nick_hempshall{at}hotmail{dot}com>

Paul O. Bartlett  grafo (mero)

>     That does bring up one thing which I think has been somewhat
> questionable all along about the design of both Interglossa and Glosa
> going back to Hogben himself, namely, the assumption that because many
> people use words containing Greek roots, they somehow know the meaning
> of those roots as if they were lexical atoms.  Elsewhere I have termed
> this the Hogben Fallacy.  These days, I suspect that even scientists or
> biological taxonomists consult dictionaries or even classical scholars
> to help with the coining of new terms or Linnaean-type names.

Hogben wrote in his book "INTERGLOSSA" (chapter 2) -

"Since Interglossa is an isolating (analytical) language, learning
Interglossa involves learning merely: (a) its etymology, i.e. mnemonic
association of each vocable to an internationally current root (Chapter XI);
(b) its semantics, i.e. analysis of the meaningful content of the vocables;
(c) its word-order; (d) its phonetics and typography."

This indicates to me [see (a) above] that he expected people to be familiar
with words like "telephone" and "microscope", whilst not knowing the
meanings of the elements that make up these words, since he says they must
"learn" the etymology.

"With a few exceptions the vocables of Interglossa are based on unmutilated
roots of words which now belong to the vocabulary of all countries where
modern technology and hygiene have penetrated. The meaning ascribed to any
one of them does not necessarily tally with the one given in a Latin or a
Greek lexicon. It is the meaning suggested by the internationally current
words in which it occurs."

This again indicates that the basis of Interglossa was this "international"
vocabulary and not a knowledge of Latin and Greek words.

Ashby & Clark, writing in "CENTRAL GLOSA" (page 9), give as the second
educational benefit of learning Glosa that -

"The great number of technical terms a modern student has to comprehend and
memorize get meaning through Glosa and so become easily memorable."

This must mean that they, like Hogben, did not believe that people already
knew the meaning of the Greek and Latin roots that make up these technical
terms.

Nick

> I was thinking more like "biting dogs", fixated as I was on
> participles. Since then, I have found -NT- embedded in so many
> Glosa roots, I feel free to use that productively.

In "The Loom of Language" by Frederick Bodmer (and edited by Lancelot
Hogben) writing about the favourable points of INTERLINGUA [Latino sine
flexione]

"Interlingua has NO mobile derivative affixes to juggle with. It is wholly
analytical, like Chinese or, we might almost add, Anglo-American. What
prefixes and suffixes remain stick firmly to the Latin or Greek loan-word
with all their diversity of meaning, contradictions and obscurities in
English, French, or Spanish usage."

Some one-time eminent support for my view of the inadvisability of the
attempted analysis of Glosa words into "meaningful" elements!

Nick

From: Charles <root{at}catty{dot}com>

[major snippage]

> > the assumption that because many
> > people use words containing Greek roots, they somehow know the meaning
> > of those roots as if they were lexical atoms.

Greek roots were usually tiny vague formative elements, not meaningful
in themselves; even what look to us like "roots" have a substructure.
Sometimes it seems there are no roots, only thicker branches.
Even in PIE roots, which were nearly/approximately C-C, there were
families of related meanings associated with certain consonants,
especially added onto the C-C pattern (vowels were ablauted).

> association of each vocable to an internationally current root (Chapter XI);

This has a clearer meaning: Hogben was thinking like "GRAPHein = write",
which would be compounded lexically rather than morphologically, IIUC.
He did not intend separate word-roots for TELEGRAPH, PHOTOGRAPH, etc.
But it's difficult to know, since he did not stay long with the project,
and his writing is the most unclear of any professional writer I have read,
especially in its syntax.

> This indicates to me [see (a) above] that he expected people to be familiar
> with words like "telephone" and "microscope", whilst not knowing the
> meanings of the elements that make up these words, since he says they must
> "learn" the etymology.

I think he meant to have "tele-fone, mikro-fone, etc", with the roots
rather prominently exposed. People do know these roots, but they are not
specific and "scientific" as in Ido. Same for the prefixes RE- DE- etc.
The way that language works is by analogical extension, not by precise
logical definition. My degree is in math, but that sort of logic doesn't
apply to human vocabulary. Humans use a more productive natural kind
of (ana-)logic. So, I finally learn to love the vague affixes and roots.

[equivocal Hogben quote snipped]

> This again indicates that the basis of Interglossa was this "international"
> vocabulary and not a knowledge of Latin and Greek words.

Ambiguous: Are we looking at scientific combining forms like "cardio-"
or common international vulgar (90% latinate) forms like "cord-ial"?

> "The great number of technical terms a modern student has to comprehend and
> memorize get meaning through Glosa and so become easily memorable."

These build-your-vocab-through-etymology claims are nothing new.
I went through a course once ... and hated the vagueness of the affixes.
I think it is better to simply collect the word-families (which are
present even in Glosa) and let human powers of pattern recognition
work their magic:

 accessibility
 accessible
 accession
 accessory
concession
concessionary
concessive
 incessant
precession
procession
processor
 recession
 recessionary
 recessive

Now, if you pronounce each word aloud slowly, you come to know
what "CESS-" means in English, without being able to explain it
in any precise way. This is the (only) way that all language works.

> This must mean that they, like Hogben, did not believe that people already
> knew the meaning of the Greek and Latin roots that make up these technical
> terms.

I agree with your analysis, but give it a different interpretation.
The root CESS- is certainly used in Glosa as above. But because of
Glosa's, ahem, mutilated phonetic spelling, CEDERE/CESSUS=cede has
meshed with CESSARE=cease to make hash of the derivational series:

cede      cede, surrender, yield
no-cede   resolute
cesa      cease
reced     recede  go back
recense   revise book
recesi    recess
procede   forward
procesa   process
procesi   process
procesio  procession

This could be untangled by using CED- vs. CESS-, or some such;
or final vowels could be used systematically, CESE- CESA-.
It requires a reform of the whole vocabulary to cure these ills.

> In "The Loom of Language" by Frederick Bodmer (and edited by Lancelot

> prefixes and suffixes remain stick firmly to the Latin or Greek loan-word
> with all their diversity of meaning, contradictions and obscurities in
> English, French, or Spanish usage."

Good reference. But again it confuses me: at first I think of
true analytical languages like Chinese or Malay or creoles,
which use productive-compounding rather than morphological affixes;
neither Interlingua nor Glosa do that predominantly. The one uses
Latin words directly, which embed a Latin morphology minus only
the syntactic affixes, *not* minus the semantic extensions.
The other (Glosa) naively jumbles words from any random source,
with separate words for different syntactic uses ...
How you gonna use "PROLONGA" as multiple parts of speech?

> Some one-time eminent support for my view of the inadvisability of the
> attempted analysis of Glosa words into "meaningful" elements!

Except that the authors support my p.o.v. strongly in their list
of vague semantic prefixes. I already posted them here recently.
Please account for the following few examples using your theory:

palin- G    back again
para- G     beside
per-        thorough, through
peri- G     around
po-, post-  after
pre-        before
pro-        forward, favor

It isn't your fault; Glosa is just inconsistent and unprincipled.
It needs an overhaul, revision, reform, redesign; and desperately.
(I've returned to this opinion after examining vocabulary recently.)

Subject: Re: [glosalist] discussiones interlinguistic
From: Michael Talbot-Wilson <mtw{at}birdseye{dot}view{dot}net{dot}au>

Ye 2000-09-09 15:33 -0700, Charles skribis:

> It would not resemble the mud-wrestling pits of AUXLANG,
> and such troublesome troll-people would be excluded;
> also, anonymous questions and postings would be permitted.
> Most especially encouraged would be messages written in
> experimental hybrids between various IALs; but likely, the
> naturalistic types would predominate (Occidental, Glosa, etc).

How do you make that happen?  Moderated lists are troublesome
things.  Lotta work, lotta responsibility.  I don't think anyone
has succeeded as you intend to do.  Good luck.

One approach, possibly, would be to require the discussions to be
in "Occidental, Glosa, etc".  That would provide a barrier to idle
entry and somewhat discourage facile controversy.  Those who had
the impertinence to design a language for others without knowing a
couple of IALs themselves would choose to go elsewhere.  Those who
knew a couple would be able to handle any of the "etc" languages
that met your criteria, not without a little effort, but with a
degree of it acceptable and interesting to language designers.

That approach has, of course, been tried in the bablo list, with
only moderate success, but the bablani are by definition a less
expert group, and there is not the restriction to naturalistic
languages that you contemplate.

If you want to do it in English in an international mailing list
you need to justify the use of English as an IAL.  There is some
incongruity in an English-language list of this kind, I think.

The "naturalistic" is the bugbear.  It is there I think you will
go wrong.  I don't know if you have a clear meaning for it.  Does
it mean there will be excessively complex, or undefined, rules of
derivation, or will the words (as I think you intend) be
invariable?  Does it mean just that the vocabulary will come from
a few languages that arose in one part of the globe?  In other
words, the contrary of a priori?  If so, perhaps there is a better
word than "naturalistic".

Basically, I'm convinced that a naturalistic language can't be a
world language.  What is needed is an autonomous language, one
amenable to complete definition, and indeed, completely defined.  
Not a semi-artificial languages.

Personally I'm pretty clueless, but the only world languages I
know of are Esperanto, Ido, and Glosa.  And I'm doubtful about the
last.  Occidental is not a candidate, mea opinione.

* The amount of words in "Core" and "Basic" should be optimized.  
  I think, maybe 1700 for "Core" and less than 4000, maybe 3700 for 
  "Basic" would be best. 
* I have to go through Bill's mails to Glosalist about his dictionary 
  work and his considerations.  The mails are collected in 
  www.tuhh.de/~smms1406/gidhist.txt.gz .  Without wanting to, I 
  certainly have destroyed some good ideas when I used the Richmond 
  data.
* The "G"s (marks of Glosa words with Greek origin) should be 
  supplemented with help of the book "Glosa 6000".  Same with 
  capitalization. 
* Some synonyms are necessary for good style and feeling comfortable 
  with a language.  But in "Core" the amount of synonyms should be 
  reduced to a minimum.  Especially the phenomenon of "different roots 
  for similar concepts" is annoying.  I started to make a list of them 
  (www.tuhh.de/~smms1406/gcosyn.htm ).  We could complete the 
  list and then fix this problem. 
* Alphabetical sorting ("{", "}", "[", "]") must be corrected. 
* The problem of "similar synonyms" (similar Glosa words with same 
  meaning, mostly differing from each other only in the ending vowel) 
  is not solved.  I started to make a list of them 
  (www.tuhh.de/~smms1406/gsimsyn.htm ).  The list should be 
  completed.  We can build up a database of classical origins to every 
  word (word pair) and of cognated words in other languages.  
  With this data we could collect examples to every Latin and 
  Greek conjugation/declination and write a "Word Derivation Scheme". 
  A start for such a scheme is www.tuhh.de/~smms1406/gwds.htm 
  (it is just what I emailed before here in Glosalist). 
  With this scheme we can choose the "right" synonym or "correct" the 
  words.  Great would be an approval by Wendy Ashby. 
* A database of classical origins and cognated words of other 
  languages should be made for the "Core"-words, too.  With the 
  "Word Derivation Scheme" we could systematize the vocabulary then 
  step by step.  

And of course:
* Correct errors
* Contact W. Ashby
* Test out the dictionary by conversation and translation work
* Translate the dictionary in various languages (German, Russian, 
  French ..)

A micro-study ... I did this unix command, and got a list
of 52 Glosa words, which I reformatted a bit below:

cut -f 3 glosatest* | grep -v '[- ]' | grep '.ekt.$' | sort -u

abjekti afekta aspekti aspekto
defekti dejekti delekta detekti dialekta dialekti direkti disekti
efekti ejekti eklekti elekti erekti expekta
genuflekti hekto injekti insekti inspekti
kolekti konekti konfekti korekti
lekto nekto objekti
perfekti perspekto plekto prefekta prefekto projekti
reflekti rejekta rekti respekta respekti retrospekti
sekta sekti selekti spekta subjekti suspekta
tekti tekto vekti vekto

It's a bit of a jungle, but by disentangling it
we can reduce the 52 chaotic words to 11 nice roots:
"fekt jekt lekt nekt rekt sekt tekt vekt flekt plekt spekt".

The prefixes are familiar: "ab ad de dia dis ex in ko per
pre pro re sub super", and some few compounds like "genu".
Then maybe some missing words like "kon-vekt" appear.

Obviously there are many other groups besides "-ect".
(Wouldn't they all sound nicer using Greek "apo-" for "ab-"?)
To reduce G-8000 to manageable size, we selekt/inspekt all
these sets, then look for more patterns among the remainder.
Maybe eliminate "-fika" words with "-fect", or the reverse.

Also apparent is the random final vowel situation.
I would make them all -e for etymological and mnemonic
reasons, but there is more to it ... crypto-suffixes!

Subject: Re: [glosalist] sur/epi
From: Robin Gaskell <rgaskell{at}zeta{dot}org{dot}au>
Date: Fri, 15 Sep 2000 22:33:43 +1000

At 09:49 31/08/2000 -0700, you wrote:
>
>Some people dislike the Latin prefixed vague prepositions,
>and find them inconsistently used and silly in Glosa,
>e.g. "su facia, su-facia, surfaci, surfacia" = "surface",
>and "superficia" = "superficial". I mean the whole set of
>"ab- ad- de- con- pre- pro- re- sub- sur-" etc.
>
*   Some of these are present in the "6000" words without hyphens,
and this makes the Glosa words look 'Latinate'.
    CON- is not Glosa, KON- is.
    Where prefixes are functional in constructing neologisms, then I feel
they ought to have a place.  However, the question of using the Greek or
the Latin form, in construction, is tricky.
    My two main thoughts are that both Greek and Latin forms should be
allowed, and that the "6000" lexicon should not be altered too drastically.
 Having said that I realise there could be mounted a strong case for going
through the lexicon and stripping out all cases of a non-preferred form,
e.g. all words beginning with ~ab~ where the initial letter s have an
undefined 'prefix' quality.

    However, there are two main determinants for me:-
 1. Both function words and substantives, in Glosa, should be spelt
consistently - for the benefits of both learners and programmers working on
the machine-handling of language.
 2. The ear should be the final arbiter in accepting words: when the words
are spoken in a sentence, does the sentence flow; and, is the meaning
readily grasped, from hearing the sentence? 

>There may be a usable alternative in the Greek prefixes, e.g.
>"dia, epi, exo". They better fit the disyllabic sound pattern
>and eliminate that just-another-Romance-interlingua feeling.
>I am wondering if it would be worth the effort to search
>systematically for replacements, e.g. SURFACIA --> EPIFACI.
>
*   I cannot tell which is the better: ~surfacia~ has an excellent
pedigree, albeit Latinate, and is readily recognisable to most speakers of
Euro-languages.
    ~epifaci~ could be the final winner because it is closer to the
"sing-song" quality of CVCVCV.  Perhaps this is the sort of question to
ask the Asian Glosa-pe.
    Whether there is space in the lexicon for three forms of the word, I am
not sure.  IE
  face     EG  Fe pa face mu sito pro mu prima-vora.
  facia        An fu face u jardina para u Nordi facia de an domi. 
  -faci        U pani-faci makina pa produce pani pro u holo komunita.
   
>This requires mixing Greek prefixes with Latin roots,
>and moves away ("ki ab") from "international vocabulary"
>and at-sight recognizability. But it seems more in
>accord with the original justification for Interglossa,
>scientific Greek vocabulary with simplified syntax.
>
*   Mixing elements works: we got away with "television."
    But I still see the idea as using ''Classical'' roots; however, I
suspect that the use of strict derivational laws will sterilise Glosa.
While I can see that fuzzy spelling will defeat the purposes of Glosa
altogether, I still feel that one, or two, well defined, and regularly-
spelt words per concept is to be aimed at; and, this was what Ron Clark and
Wendy Ashby generally derived - albeit often through intuitive means,
rather than via a formula.

>As it is today, I can't see how to use Glosa seriously,
>it's too much of a mish-mash. I re-sorted the vocab
>roughly by roots and find things like this everywhere,
>even basic stuff like "make, build, face":
>
>faba            bean
>faber           artisan
>fabrika         structure
*   Maybe the first two are too close in sound, though context would
certainly sort out the bean from the being.  So, an "artisan" might be a
person who makes things, a ~fabrika-pe~.

>bene-face       do good
*   Fits the pattern, but hard to use in a sentence.
    ~U holo viki gene bene-face ex an ergo.~
    ~Fe bene-face fe sko-do ko fe kali kanta.~ 

>lega-face       legislation
*   I prefer to avoid this awkward word, by treating "laws" and "making
laws" as two different linguistic situations.
   EG  ~An sio aplika plu lega.~  He would apply the laws (legislation).
       ~Durante u lega-face procesa, fe pa skope plura mega bibli.~
        During the law-making process, she looked at several large books.


>face            build, construct, make, manufacture, produce
>face-do         factory
*   Seems OK.

>faci            making
*   If this is to be preserved, then I'd say it should be in the form of a
hyphenated suffix, IE ~-faci~.  And the only justification might be that
the long sound of the E at the end of the word is not as suitable as the
short sound of I for compound formation. 

>facia           face, features, surface
*   As faces and surfaces can be shown to be semantically related, this
word seems adequate for both usages.  And it is sufficiently distinct from
~face~, in sound and appearance, to warrant entry in the lexicon. 

>facu u neo ra   invent
*   I'd say that this U was one too many.
    Also, I don't know it source: at the time that the terminal vowel was
not fixed, an article could have been written including this spelling;
however, now that terminal vowels are prescribed, this "Old Glosa" should
be 'retired.'

>ge-face         artificial, produce
>ge-face ex      consist
*   Not sure of the sources of these usages: they just dont feel right.
Firstly, the ~ge-X~ form has been fairly well discussed on this list to be
the Glosa equivalent of the 'past participle' in English: I'd say either
these definitions are in error, or are archaic.
  EG
 Id pa gene ge-face intra Deutschland.
 Durante u holo di fe pa produce solo tri itema de vesti.
 U tegu-vesti ne dona termo, ka id es ge-face de no-natura textili.
 U di produce, de u holo face-do, eqa six kilo unita.
  &
 U sani-bibi gene ge-face, per u paleo andra, ex plura natura herba.
 Id konsiste de poli pusi mero de vitri, ge-jugo ko fo poli longi mero de   
   tenu metali-fi. 
 U kali modela de u facia pa gene ge-face ex mo mero de ligni.  

>no-face         demolish, destroy, havoc, undo
*   Don't know if I can agree with these definitions: ~no-face~ distinctly
means "un-make", and while we might 'un-make' a bed, we need a much more
drastic word to describe pulling down a building.
  EG
 U gina pa no-face u kli; qi pa previo gene ge-face ex fe fe-fili.
 U milita-pe pa destru u ge-tekto-ra, per explode id.
 An pa es u fo laxi andra; qi holo-tem pa somni intra u no-ge-face kli.
 Tri andra fu demoli, brika ex brika, u kloro ge-kroma domi. 
 U hero pa no-liga u forti liga-fi; peri fe plu karpus.

>su facia        surface
>su-facia        surface
*   More problems: "6000" gives 'SURFACE facia' and 'FACIA face, surface'.
    Strictly speaking, the ~su facia~ is the space above the surface.  
  EG
 Intra u su facia de u gra agri, na detekti plu kilo de pusi insekti.
 U ju-an singu di pa re-veni ad an domi ko u su-facia lamina de sordi.

>faceta          facet
>faceti          witty
>
*   O.K. if the Glosa lexicon allows for entries that differ only in their
final vowel.  If, as here, the menings are quite distiinct, then context,
as well as the final vowel, will separate the words.

>So now I don't know whether to consider Glosa as possible
>euro-pidgin (bene-face, lega-face, fabri-domi, epi-face)
>or anglo-latin (beneficial, surface, facetious, invention).
>I'd really like to know how others see it ...
>
*   For the first question, I would take 50-50 odds: for vocabulary, Glosa
is a sort of Classico-creole; while for its construction, it is more Anglo,
but not very Latin.
    Imagine a time .. in prehistory .. when early man though little before
uttering, and barely distinguished between things and their actions.  In
such a mystic stage of evolution, the concepts echoing thought were also
closely related to the sounds used to convey these thoughts: it is
postulated, here, that proto-man used proto-language in a very loose way,
such that metaphorical usage blurred the boundaries between the concrete
and the abstract, and simple, largely un-inflected sounds were used to
string these thoughts together.
    Now imagine a time .. in post-history .. when civilised man painfully,
urgently seeks to rediscover the fundamentals of communication to
facilitate intercommunication between groups whose long linguistic
evolutions have driven them apart.  In such a time there will be attempts
to impose the most evolved of civilisation's national languages on all;
alternatively, there will be attempts to marshal the best linguistic
features into one superior language; while others will suggest a return to
some form of linguistic Lowest Common Denominator.
    As I see it, Glosa represents the thrust from this last group.  To get
man talking to man, we might have to take a few steps back - to a level of
sophistication where people from all linguistic traditions can cope.

Saluta,

Robin

> On Thu, 14 Sep 2000, Charles wrote (small excerpt):

> > Glosa has a crypto-derivational non-system. It needs a complete
> > redesign and replacement, I really think so.

>     In which case you are free to design your own language.

If so, is not Glosa fatally flawed?  It seems to me that the only
alternatives are it's remediable or it's fatal.

Glosa has derivation, the problem is that it's not designed in,
it's naturalistic, and the significance of the denied affix must
be acquired along with the root as a single concept.  If we
confessed that we had roots and pre-defined affixes we would have
a more intelligible language.

Look at Sweet's chapter on derivation in English.  Look at the
treatment of that chapter in the synoptic table of contents,
giving page references to, what, 180 affixes.

Is that what you want for Glosa, the need for someone to write a
large book describing the language found in the wild, or do you
want an IAL with a simple and complete definition?

P.S. I mean Sweet's "New English Grammar".

Michael Talbot-Wilson wrote:

> > > Glosa has a crypto-derivational non-system. It needs a complete

> If so, is not Glosa fatally flawed?  It seems to me that the only
> alternatives are it's remediable or it's fatal.

Glosa claims to be a global IAL. As such it must meet some criteria,
it's own and those of its potential users. Seems to me that Glosa
is not true to its own principles, thus the problem. The result
is that nobody can actually write in it without extreme difficulty.

I see no reason to design a new language. The international language
(European style) aleady exists. Glosa barely qualifies as a dialect.
Novial, Occidental, and both Interlinguas are the prime examples.
People can speak any combination of these and be mutually understood.
With somewhat careful selection of vocabulary, they can be adapted
to speaking with native Euro-language speakers who have not even
studied any interlingue or even heard tale of such.

Glosa is not defensible in its current state, it needs redesign work.
I push for: 1) Identify what Glosa's principles are; 2) Follow them.
Examination of the extended vocabulary reveals chaos. There are
obvious ways to fix the problems. I will not accept any "Hands-off!"
statements of people who do not actually support and use the language.
I've tried to use it, and now re-affirm that it does not work, as-is.

> Glosa has derivation, the problem is that it's not designed in,

Good points here and about Sweet, and I agree, so I delete them.

I wonder if my last message made it to the list?
Maybe wasn't so unusually interesting as I thought ...

kolekti konekti konfekti korekti
lekto nekto objekti
perfekti perspekto plekto prefekta prefekto projekti
reflekti rejekta rekti respekta respekti retrospekti
sekta sekti selekti spekta subjekti suspekta
tekti tekto vekti vekto

It's a bit of a jungle, but by disentangling it
we can reduce the 52 chaotic words to 11 nice roots:
"fekt jekt lekt nekt rekt sekt tekt vekt flekt plekt spekt".

The prefixes are familiar: "ab ad de dia dis ex in ko per
pre pro re sub super", and some few compounds like "genu".
Then maybe some missing words like "kon-vekt" appear.

Obviously there are many other groups besides "-ect".
(Wouldn't they all sound nicer using Greek "apo-" for "ab-"?)
To reduce G-8000 to manageable size, we selekt/inspekt all
these sets, then look for more patterns among the remainder.
Maybe eliminate "-fika" words with "-fect", or the reverse.

Also apparent is the random final vowel situation.
I would make them all -e for etymological and mnemonic
reasons, but there is more to it ... crypto-suffixes!

> The Greeks a pretty good at swallowing vowels.  In practice the
> "apo" would be pronounced "ap" in many cases.  So you are arguing
> for a voiceless "b" instead of a voiced "b".

Most of the A- vocabulary is either AB- or AD- plus verbal root.
The AD- tends to assimilate nicely and all the IALs allow A=AD.
But AB- is fairly ugly to pronounce, whereas AP(O)- is flexible,
sounds better and has exactly the same meaning. It would make
auto-hyphenation (and thus identification of roots) much easier.
But even a small change like that would rattle cages; even though
Glosa supposedly favors Greek ... It was just a thought.

I do argue for identifying all those hidden roots, and
either a(d)-cept-ing or e(x)-ject-ing the whole lot.

Robin Gaskell grafo (mikro mero)
> the "6000" lexicon should not be altered too drastically.

For me, the description of G6000 in the Glosa Publications list is
instructive.
"6000 Greek and Latin Words and Roots which occur in the Euro-languages and
the International Scientific Terminology"
"Readership:
This dictionary gives the meanings of Greek and Latin roots used in
medicine, biology, plant and animal names etc. Suitable for educationalists,
students, linguists and for Glosa enthusiasts."

This tells me that G6000 has never been intended to be the "heart" of Glosa.
It is just a interesting exercise to demonstrate the "Hogben Principle" that
there is no need to invent an international vocabulary as an excellent one
already exists and has been waiting to be more widely used for at least the
last three centuries (i.e. the Vocabulary of Science).

In contrast the Glosa Publications list gives as the readership for CENTRAL
GLOSA
"Readership:
Ideal for beginners of Glosa, advanced students and teachers of Glosa."

This tells me that G1000 IS the "heart" of Glosa. Hogben's aim was always
for a language for all the world, and so one having the greatest possible
word economy, and a rationally constructed word list that would cover all
the essential words of intercommunication. The language should contain a
judicious selection of general terms and descriptive periphrase for specific
uses.

Ashby and Clark write "The authors consider that the Glosa presented here in
this book (CENTRAL GLOSA) is the most important Glosa....Glosa 1000. By
calling it Central Glosa it is hoped that the reader will never lose sight
of its central importance. If Glosa is to become truly Interglosa, the
International Auxiliary Language, it must remain simple. Comfortable
westerners might quickly get lost in Mega Glosa, forgetting the baser
degrees by which they ascended."
  "We hope that students who might get involved in the seeming luxury of
Mega-Glosa will quickly work up to Central Glosa, which involves clear
thinking."
  "Glosa 1000 is not only capable of great accuracy, but is also capable of
any degree of subtlety."

My understanding of the term "Mega-Glosa" is that it is all rest of the
"international" words that we might want occasionally to use for euphony or
variety. This is said to be a very large vocabulary of words, and clearly
goes beyond those words listed in the G6000 book.

: A prima vista posi id feno u no-spe ergo de face u verba-lista; qi fu sati

> I am very poor at retaining vocabulary, which is the primary
> reason I write very little in *any* conIAL.  Once there is a more
> agreed upon selection of central vocabulary, I might give it a try
> again.  But apart from a judicious selection of vocabulary from already
> existing materials, I see no pressing need to make changes in the
> language itself.

But with a proper design, very little learning should be needed
for any European, because we already know all those word-roots
through Greco-Latin derivative words in English; they are even
more transparent to other eurolang speakers. And apparently,
the authors say this version of Glosa is *not* yet "Interglosa",
the global IAL, so this must be the euro-regional version!

Here is how to do the vocab: list prefixes, suffixes, roots.
But please *not* 6000 randomized "word stems", or 27000 as in Ila.
Here are 26 magnificent roots, to be multiplied by 10 prefixes
apiece, times 10 suffixes on the average, yielding 2600 useful
and immediately recognizable words, most of which *are* in Glosa
but *hidden* by the amateurish pseudo-phonetic spelling:

act auct coct dact dict duct fact fect fict flect flict fract frict
ject lect nect pact pict rect sect spect suct tect tract vect vict

But many are missing from Glosa, like "convect". We sense these
lacunae in the vocab but can't find them, because there is no
discernable system to it. So I recommend we impose a rational system,
derived/extracted/analyzed/extrapolated from the existing G-vocab.
According to my reading of the materials, users are justified
and permitted/allowed/encouraged to do exactly that.

> There is no such thing as a "perfect" auxiliary lang

But there are better and worse. Esperanto and Glosa-present are
not even good enough to withstand a stiff breeze (of fresh air).
But at least Glosa is reformable; it has some resources for evolution.
Any language that cannot be evolved is flat-out *dead*.

> > Novial, Occidental, and both Interlinguas are the prime examples.
> 
>     In which case, to be honest, it puzzles me as to why you are active
> here.  So far as I know, you have been a vocal advocate of Occidental.

Occidental did not resist reform, it encouraged it.
Eventually most adherents went over to Gode's dictionary.
But one cannot actually learn a dictionary, one needs a system.
Naturalism is the right path, I am certain, because no other way
will work for most adults, who have *no* time to re-learn vocab;
we must find it already deep within our native languages.
Glosa accepts this pan-euro-vocabulary, but tries to impose
analytic (English) syntax upon it, with *good* results.
Occidental also uses such analyticism, to a lesser degree.

To reform the vocab means making some *changes* to it. I am
highly amused that people whine whenever this is actually attempted!

> > I've tried to use it, and now re-affirm that it does not work, as-is.
> 
>     Oh?  Several years ago I successfully used Glosa with two letters
> each way from and to a man in China who said that he knew little (if
> any) English (and I know no Chinese language).  It certainly worked
> then.

Me too, but I meant as a real living language, not just a code book.
The international language of Europe must be spoken and heard, not
just talked about or practiced like algebra or crossword-puzzles ...

Robin Gaskell (mikro mero)
>
> >facu u neo ra   invent
> *   I'd say that this U was one too many.
>     Also, I don't know it source: at the time that the terminal vowel was
> not fixed, an article could have been written including this spelling;
> however, now that terminal vowels are prescribed, this "Old Glosa" should
> be 'retired.'

The source for this is the 1993 book Central Glosa. Unfortunately a typo as
crept in here as the book gives ~face u mero ra~, and also a Greek synonym
~eureka~. "18 Step" in its "English - Glosa 1000" section gives ~inventi~.
As Marcel has pointed out in an earlier post, these "definition
translations" are hard to use in practice.

Inventing is fun.  ?? ~Face u neo ra es hedo.~
Edison invented the electric light bulb.  ?? ~Edison pa face u neo ra, qi es
u elektro foto bulbo.~
Inventor  ?? ~neo-ra face-pe~
a useful invention  ?? ~u funktio ge-neo-face ra~

Re "prescribed terminal vowels" - What makes you think that that is the
case? One of the things we been posting about recently is their variability,
even within the a few page in the same section of a book.


> >ge-face         artificial, produce
> >ge-face ex      consist
> *   Not sure of the sources of these usages: they just dont feel right.
> Firstly, the ~ge-X~ form has been fairly well discussed on this list to be
> the Glosa equivalent of the 'past participle' in English: I'd say either
> these definitions are in error, or are archaic.

These are from the same 1993 book.
"artificial", as in ~plu ge-face flori~ or ~u ge-face lingua~
"produce" - this is shown as ~u ge-face~, therefore produce in the nominal
sense, as in, ~U ge-face de face-do gene fero per trena.~
"consist", this is another of the "definition translations", perhaps this
can be expanded into, ~U sukro-sito pa gene face ex plu banana e sukro
krema.~

> >no-face         demolish, destroy, havoc, undo
> *   Don't know if I can agree with these definitions: ~no-face~ distinctly
> means "un-make", and while we might 'un-make' a bed, we need a much more
> drastic word to describe pulling down a building.

Of course, ~no-~ is used to form opposites in Glosa, where as English "un-"
usually only shows negatives, which is not the same thing. So if ~face~
means "make", the opposite would be "demolish, destroy", and if ~face~ can
mean "do", its opposite would be "undo". "Un-make" as in "un-make a bed" is
surely only ~no-sistema u kli~. "Havoc" = "widespread damage, destruction,
or devastation" and so fits in fine as the opposite of "make".

> This tells me that G6000 has never been intended to be the "heart" of Glosa.

Scientific vocabulary was Hogben's intent. Also, analytic syntax.
So far, so good ...

> there is no need to invent an international vocabulary

This is true, and fantastic. But the implication is that
literate Europeans do not need to learn it, they already know it.
This takes it all out of the hands of language creators!

> G1000 IS the "heart" of Glosa.

G1000 is a set of example words, most unrecognizable.
It is a poor collection of international words or roots.

> If Glosa is to become truly Interglosa, the
> International Auxiliary Language, it must remain simple.

Simple in syntax, yes. Also the vocab should not need to be
learned as if it were an apriori or artificially-mangled list.

> the term "Mega-Glosa"

Where's the "Micro-Glosa" that people might really use?
Sorry, I'm feeling hyper-critical lately. Glosa needs
reform! Here's my idea for people to shoot at:

1. Determine to what degree a pidgin/creole is desired.
This would be ideal for a global auxlang.
But it's not an all-or-none proposition.

2. Determine to what degree at-sight-recognition is desired.
This is ideal for a regional (euro-) auxlang.
Only a lunatic would start from apriori ... hmm.

3. Now design a grammar in accordance with 1 & 2.
Try it, test it, use it, but don't "defend" it.
Instead, identify weak points, change them, iterate.

4. Provide a usable lexicon. This is where Glosa fails.
But it is correctable.

So, I would start with Glosa as-is, and reform the vocabulary
to use well-defined roots and affixes. I think a list of
500 *recognizable* roots and under 100 affixes and particles
is sufficient for Micro-Glosa. If it really worked at all,
people would be posting in it from day one. New roots would be
suggested and added, unproductive/troublesome ones dropped.

Perhaps this would be an acceptable idea for the list:
People should nominate their own favorite roots and write
short paragraphs *using* them. Then we read and steal
from each other, augmenting our personal dictionaries.
Results might be very surprising.

characteristics are not going to be the primary determinant of whether
an auxiliary language comes into widespread use or not.

>                                 Esperanto and Glosa-present are
> not even good enough to withstand a stiff breeze (of fresh air).

    Oh, I don't know.  Esperanto has lasted for 113 years and has quite
a few periodicals and published works, with probably at present more
users than all other conIALs put together.  Like it or not -- and I
don't particularly -- Esperanto certainly works for the purposes to
which its speakers put it, and I doubt that it is going to disappear
from the conIAL scene anytime soon.

> But at least Glosa is reformable; it has some resources for evolution.
> Any language that cannot be evolved is flat-out *dead*.

    Evolution or change of fiat by people who don't happen to like this
feature or that?  IALdom is replete with the corpses of language
projects by people who thought they could do a better job.  No
constructed auxiliary language is ever going to be able to satisfy
everybody in all its features.

> Occidental did not resist reform, it encouraged it.

    Ask Bob Petry about reforming Occidental by those who are not
already active supporters and users of it.

> Eventually most adherents went over to Gode's dictionary.
> But one cannot actually learn a dictionary, one needs a system.

    Such as the Gode and Blair Interlingua Grammar.  Interlingua
certainly works.  It is used constantly on the interlng mailing list.

> Naturalism is the right path, I am certain, because no other way
> will work for most adults, who have *no* time to re-learn vocab;

    So monoglot adult speakers of Mandarin, Turkish, Aymara, and Tamil
will not have to relearn vocabulary for your European-based IAL?  Or
are you not targeting them?  Again, if all you want is an IAL for
WENSAns, I suggest sticking to Occ or Ia.

> To reform the vocab means making some *changes* to it. I am
> highly amused that people whine whenever this is actually attempted!

    Or maybe, rather than whining, they are really asserting that all
that needs to be done is select more judiciously from already existing
materials.  People are not whining just because they disagree with you.

> : studi id mega tem te detekti u mega mero de lista es ne-nece.

Yes, I've done the same. It is certainly very far from Hogben's rigidly
fixed syntax, and imposible to devise a neat set of simple rules from. But
is it "replete with impenetrable idioms"? I have seen some "shocking"
anglicisms from time to time, but it is not unusual for second language use
to be infuenced by your first language.

Re "Relexing" - Robin has said more than once that Glosa translates word for
word into English, but English cannot be translated word for word into
Glosa. If you look at your Glosa quote above, and compare it to the English
original -

"it may seem" becomes ~posi id feno~
"that" becomes ~qi~
"cover"  becomes ~sati~
"essential words" becomes ~nece volu~
"yet" becomes ~sed~
"say" becomes ~posi~
"assumes aquaintance with" becomes ~uti~
"perhaps" becomes ~minimo~
"some" becomes ~proxi~
"It requires no lengthy scrutiny" becomes ~Pe ne nece stude id mega tem~
"material" become ~lista~

This seems to suggest that meaning is being translated, not words.

Subject: Re: [glosalist] Re: dictionary
From: Michael Talbot-Wilson <mtw{at}birdseye{dot}view{dot}net{dot}au>

At 2000-09-16 19:06 -0400, Paul O. Bartlett wrote:

> On Sat, 16 Sep 2000, Charles wrote (excerpted):
> 
> > Naturalism is the right path, I am certain, because no other way
> > will work for most adults, who have *no* time to re-learn vocab;

You appear to be thinking of naturalism as the alternative to
apriorism.  To me it is the alternative to autonomy, to complete
definition.  It has very little to do with whether words have come
out of Europe or out of a machine.

I am perplexed by the enduring attraction of naturalism.  It seems
so obviously mistaken, at least as it applies to word derivation,
and a refusal to fully define the language.  What's wrong with
defining it?

Naturalism means that people from non-European linguistic groups
don't only have to learn the vocabulary.  That is hard work if the
words are all alien, but at least they are there in the
dictionary.

But naturalism, I think, means that they must somehow acquire
linguistic practices that are nowhere defined and are not capable
of simple definition.  I just don't understand it.  Naturalism
turns its back on a world interlanguage, aiming only for a
regional one.  And for what?  I just can't see the decisive
benefit which would justify such an extreme trade-off.

There is at least one (perhaps only one) autonomous and simple
IAL.  It is almost fully defined, almost totally excludes the
need to infer unstated rules from one's native language.  It only
falls short of absolute autonomy, as far as I can see, in the
existence of a very few French idiomatic phrases, which are,
however, expressly set forth in its 'Complete Manual'.

What is the matter with such a language?  Why not just learn it,
and move on?  What on earth is the attraction of naturalism?  Why
the die-hard supporters of a concept that as far as I can see
hasn't got a feather to fly with?  Is this science?

>     So monoglot adult speakers of Mandarin, Turkish, Aymara, and Tamil
> will not have to relearn vocabulary for your European-based IAL?  Or
> are you not targeting them?  Again, if all you want is an IAL for
> WENSAns, I suggest sticking to Occ or Ia.

The question of learning or re-learning vocabulary is an insoluble
one.  There is nothing for it but to do it.  But at least there is
the dictionary.  Everything is defined, you know what you know and
what you don't, and in the latter case you know what to do about
it.

This is where the minimal vocabulary theories, the Basic English
stuff, can make a contribution.  The selection of the core
vocabulary, the first thousand or so words, is very important.  
The insistence on simple language, the refusal to import into the
language words meeting every subtlety of meaning, is also very
important.

But we get nowhere criticising the West European or WENSA
provenance of the words.  They have to come from somewhere.  If
they were taken in a democratic and even-handed way from every
language of the world, or if they were generated a priori, they'd
be difficult for everyone.  To make them easy for some is not a
crime.  

If you would prefer them to be easy for someone ELSE, show me all
the Hindi-based and Cantonese-based IALs.  There was nothing to
stop people from designing them.  India has about 12 major
languages, surely a fertile field out of which the IAL concept
could have arisen.  But the fact is that the concept and the
implementations have come out of Europe.

I'm sorry this is so off-topic.  Let's get back to Glosa.

Subject: [glosalist] Translating into Glosa
From: Charles <root{at}catty{dot}com>
Date: Sat, 16 Sep 2000 19:42:52 -0700


I was looking at this bit by Edgar De Wahl, written
in the constantly evolving Occidental of 1925.
It is no-way pidgin, neither is it unusually
sophisticated in sentence structure:

: Li ver economie ne consiste
: in payar vili precies a reciver brac e desvaloralia,
: ma in acquisition del max bon e durabil materie o instrumente
: quel posse persister in omni occasiones.

So here I have tried to translate into Glosa,
using only *attested* vocabulary:

: U veri economi ne konsiste
: in paga vili preci a gene brakte e no-valu kosa,
: sed in aqire de maxi boni e dura materia alo ru
: qi posi tenacio in omni okasio.

The words "economy consist tenacious/persist occasion"
are all official Glosa, not compounds of my devising.
The words "u alo ru qi" are the sorest thumbs, IMO.
But even the recognizable latinate words suffer from
lack of appropriate endings so the syntax is vague.
Probably needs more particles. But I'm tired already;
every latinate word has unpredictable spelling,
so each word must be looked-up. Oddly, only "persist"
seemed to be missing, though "receive" has only
"gain" as an equivalent, qi es ne boni. Like Ila,
Glosa tethers the user to the dictionary.

A sphere has the highest volume per surface-area ratio.

> The question of learning or re-learning vocabulary is an insoluble

Skip that step, we already know the words.
Think of English words with -ion or -ive or -able.

one can study in a mass rather than individually.

> vocabulary, the first thousand or so words, is very important.

Exactly: re- de- con- etc. -LECT- -FECT- etc.

Language teachers have us convinced we need to invest years,

> be difficult for everyone.  To make them easy for some is not a
> crime.

Exactimen.

latinate super-productive internationally-known words.
They just need some polishing and a spotlight.
And then, maybe a few nice regular+natural suffixes ...
Let's take the best from Ido (regular word-composition)
and try to find that in Glosa; prefixes are already done.

At 2000-09-16 20:11 -0700, Charles wrote:


> > The insistence on simple language, the refusal to import into the
> > language words meeting every subtlety of meaning, is also very
> > important.
> 
> No good, adults need real adult language. The latinate

To be brief, I'll respond on this only.  Simple does not mean
childish.  Charles Dickens wrote a number of books in which people
agree to meet, in the street and elsewhere, but inexplicably he
always (I think) avoided the word "rendevous".  If I'm not
mistaken, Thomas Hardy is another good example, and I expect that
many accomplished authors would fit the pattern.  Simple writing
is forceful.  They say the Bible has a small vocabulary, yet it
deals with a great variety of public and private life.  Again
there is life in the street, there are meetings, and troops
assemble, but never rendevous.

The best writing is simple and direct, but people, those of not
the highest linguistic endowment, i.e. very, very many people, are
perpetually attracted to redundant coinings which can become
fashionable.  They seem essential, because they are exactly of the
context and the time, but they are totally unnecessary.

There are also redundant pairs, such as 'ox' and 'beef', 'sheep'
and 'mutton', that seem essential to English speakers, yet result
from a non-linguistic cause, an accident of history.

If we don't carefully exclude what is really inessential, what is
redundant, we insupportably increase the vocabulary of the
language.

Of course there is much of the world of the last 1000 years, and
of modern technology, that is not encompassed by the vocabulary of
the Bible.  We need new words, but we must be discriminating, not
admit what is inessential.  Our test should be severe.

*   While I can agree with Charles' desire for a "good" standardisation
between Classical source and latter-day Glosa, I feel that, taking the
sophistication of Civilisation into account, we cannot always go back to
the purity of using the exact forms of the Classical roots in Glosa.

    The Classical world was fairly meagre, when it came to concepts - by
contrast with our modern technological Civilisation.  So, I fear this
historical development requires us to ^fill in some of the cracks^ between
the basic Greek and Latin roots.

    Regarding CEDE and CESA I could make out a case for saying that 'moving
ones position' and 'stopping' are ^two sides of the one coin^.  Hence,
right from the start, these two concepts could have been intertwined and
even used interchangably.

>cede                         cesa                 recense           
>no-cede                      procesa              recesi  
>recede                                            procesio  
>procede   
  CEDE                         CESA                 /other

   I can imagine seeing the bottles moving .. and stopping .. on the
assembly line.  This would allow for the *forward movement* and continual
*stopping* as the contents were squirted into the bottle during the filling 
"process" (PRO - CESA).

Saluta,

Oh, I disagree ... Nothing is new under the sun.
America is the modern Rome, and English phrasal verbs
are directly parallel with Latin, but non-international.

>     Regarding CEDE and CESA I could make out a case for saying that 'moving
> ones position' and 'stopping' are ^two sides of the one coin^.

Indeed, but more like multi-sided dice ... recede recess,
procede process, precede precess, concede (= concess), accede access,
(ab-cede?) abcess, (in-cede?) incess(ant) ... and so on!
This is the Glosa core vocabulary, and the core international vocab.

Taking words in their proper forms, they are 100% regular and easy.
The CEDE/CESA words point the way to re-organizing the Glosa-8000
into a few hundred core root-concepts that generate word families.
This solves the problem of having too many unrelated words,
without throwing-out, e-ject-ing, or a-bol-ishing any.

> > > The insistence on simple language,

> Simple does not mean childish. [...] Simple writing is forceful.

Agreed, an IAL must *not* be simple as in "makeshift pidgin jargon",
but *must* be simple as in "direct and powerful but easy to learn".
These are not contradictory in a well-designed IAL.
The heart of an IAL is not a vocab list, which must evolve,
but rather its principles, which need to remain consistent.
Any IAL must use the international word roots and affixes.
If we keep returning to this base concept, we cannot go wrong.

> There are also redundant pairs, such as 'ox' and 'beef', 'sheep'

> If we don't carefully exclude what is really inessential, what is
> redundant, we insupportably increase the vocabulary of the language.

Right, those small non-international words must be excluded,
whereas BOV- and VAC- are international and form many useful
derivatives. It is not so easy to do this properly, though ...
"vaccinate, vaccine" comes originally from "vacca = cow",
but "bovine = cow" is now used internationally for the animal.

On Sun, 17 Sep 2000, Robin Gaskell wrote (very small excerpt):

>                                   and which depends, for its regularity, on
> the innate language sense of the utterers.

    I must demur here.  There are those who assert that there is a
deep structure, or some such thing, to grammar.  I will not address
that point, as I think it is unnecessary here.  I fear that what Robin
is referring to here as "the innate language sense of the the utterers"
is no more than native language conditioning, and that varies all over
the map all over the world.  We must be very, very, very, very, very
careful not to confuse what seems "natural" to us, due to our own
language conditioning, with what seems "natural" to everybody.  That is
why I think that, didactically, a language with almost no grammatical
morphology such as Glosa needs to have its syntactic structures
effectively specified, if not formally then by a comprehensive set of
not only paradigmatic sentences but also paradigmatic connected texts.

From: Charles <root{at}catty{dot}com>

> Latin itself did not have nearly the size of vocabulary that
> English does.  (Few languages did/do.)  Does that mean that Latin
> was/is (it's still alive) not a "real adult language"?

They say that Latin and Greek derivational systems could easily
handle any challenge one could present to them; even tele-vision ...
English incorporates many different roots for similar concepts,
where L & G used affixes to "nuance" the relatively few roots.
English turned out more "regular" but L & G more "systematic",
(at least in some senses, as we are probably all aware by now).
Our international language must combine their strengths,
but carefully avoid their weaknesses.

I am looking at the verbs first, because there is a large set
of very useful and mnemonically related international roots,
LECT etc, easily combinable with the prepositions CO- etc.
>From verbs one derives agents, results, states, etc.
So one word expands into 100 ... With just a few of those,
we can generate a huge at-sight-recognizable vocab in hours.
Those words are all to be found hiding within the Glosa vocab.
They are the true core learner vocab.

I have finally looked at Marcel's list of "missing" words,
present in the English common-word lists and not in Glosa,
but I disagree that they are really missing:

absence    ... ABSENTIA
acceptable ... ACEPTABILI
accordance ... AKORDANTIA
accuracy   ... EXAKTI MODE, AKURA MODE

Should all the derivatives be listed in the dictionary?
Peano and De Wahl and Jesperson all used a compressed
list format, indicating derivatives sorta like:

A-CEPT -a, -ant(e), --ia, -abili

I think they should be written out more fully,
but listed together in proper word-families,
which makes study 1000 times easier:

-CEPT-
	acept-, koncept-, recept- ...
	-ceptabili -ception -ceptive -ceptentie

-LECT-
	...
	...

-MAN-
	...
	...

Or maybe each prefix-ed form requires a separate line,
because the meanings are not entirely apparent;
and maybe the suffixed forms too:

-CEPT-
koncept-
recept-
...
-ceptabili
-ception
...

But we need cannot list all the combined forms separately,
there are far too many: reception, acceptable, ... ad inf.
And it seems to me that most if not all international words
are inherently part of Glosa, whether listed anywhere or not.
Of course it's good evidence if the root is attested somewhere ...

About http://www.tuhh.de/~smms1406/gidmiss.htm ...

> The list shows important English words that are not in
> (my suggestion of a) "Core"-dictionary.

>  > absence    ... ABSENTIA
> 
> "ABSENTIA" does not satisfy me, when we take "AB" for "absent".

AB is simply the prefix known in all IE languages, "away from",
officially included in Glosa's list of prefixes; ABS is a variant spelling
used in cases like this, where the compound is really AB-ES (essence, ES, to be)
plus -NT (Latin present participle) plus -IA (abstract noun suffix).
English absent/absence are the same word with different part-of-speech.
It is extremely international, therefore indispensible, unfortunately
messy too. We could use "reanalysis = popular etymology" to cheat:
pretend it is AB-SENT = "be or feel sent away from" or something.

> I think, it was Paul who wrote: English is the world language to beat.

English is not a world language in any sense. It is like French 150 years
ago. And the same thing prevents it being an IAL: lousy pronunciation,
despite good spelling of the international words. People who favor
phonetic spelling of English are killing it as an IAL ... fortunately!

> (Perhaps "AB-TEM", "AB-LO", "AB-STATUS" or courageous "U AB"?)

It's just no good to ignore the international vocabulary.
ABSENT/ABSENCE is PRESENT in every European language.
I have zero interest in any so-called IAL that is effectively apriori.

> "CEPTI" is Glosa1000, prefered for "accept".  So "CEPTI-ABILI".  Maybe
> "CEPTI" is enough?

Not really ... looks like "septic" to me. It is better to leave
the words long enough to be easily recognizeable. What's the hurry
nowadays? People need to slow down and enjoy all the syllables ...

> Maybe "AKORDA"/"U AKORDA" is enough?  Or "HARMONI"?

Both "accept/recept/decept/..." and "accord/discord/record/..."
word families are certainly needed.

>  > accuracy   ... EXAKTI MODE, AKURA MODE

> "accuracy" is missing.

Not a bit: see KURA, the most overused Glosa root of all.
It compounds with AD to make AD-KURA = AKURA.

> Your "ABSENTIA", "ACEPTABILI" and "AKORDANTIA" are not in the Glosa
> Internet Dictionary yet.

They are inherent in Glosa, according to the sources.
You can't eliminate the prefixed words, and shouldn't want to.
Furthermore, ABILI is given in a hundres places as a suffix.
I have shown that -IA and -IO and others are also suffixes.

> I do not think that it is Glosa what you are doing there, it is more
> Ido or Volapük.

No. Please do not accuse me of making a new language project.
That is the filth from lunatic Jay Bowks, who has entered every
IAL discussion group only to sow discord and promote his favorite,
which is certainly not Glosa. I do not want any new IALs.
The only IALs worth considering are those based on the Greco-Latin
international vocabulary, which all can freely mix as dialects.
Within the territories of Ido/Novial, Occidental, and Glosa
can be found all that is necessary for the true IAL.

I have revised my view of Glosa trying to match that of the authors.
It is not a pidgin at all. It is a naive relex of English using
a pocket Italian-English dictionary. Thus it inherited all the
prefixes and suffixes of Greco-Latin. Not my fault!

> - But: Glosa can build new words with the existing words, connecting
>   them with hyphens.  That is powerful.

Simple word compounding is fun but insufficient;
one needs a system. Look at ABILI and KURA in the
materials we just typed ... When I tried translating
word-for-word from Occidental to Glosa I was amazed;
every word but one was in Glosa directly, though in
the messy ABSENTI form you don't like (but I do).

Now *I* am the Glosa conservative, and *you* are the radical
imposing a new vision of pidgin-vocab that the authors
did not clearly intend. You can't throw out the latinate words
and call it Glosa, you dangerous revolutionary!

Joking aside: As we analyze it, clearly Glosa needs some
new clear definitions and directions from Wendy. Should it
become more like the naturalistic IALs, using roots, prefixes
and suffixes? Or should it go pidgin/creole? It doesn't
make much sense as it is right now, halfway between.
If if remains ill-defined and non-systematic, it can't compete
with other IALs. I would like to see it rejuvenated somehow.

For Charles, a "cheap" way to Occideglossa: 

* Occidental uses: -ion, -or, -ori, -iv, -ura, -t. 
* -ion and -ura are close together, I think, not both are necessary. 

* Glosa has the ge- for -t and -pe for -or already.  
* Glosa takes the naked word for -ion, -ori, -iv, -ura.  
* It can form nouns with u/plu and with -ra.  
* -ion is in many Glosa words as -io like petitio, tensio already, 
    but without a meaning! 
* Glosa would allow a combination with -status for -ion. 

Using the existing ge-, -pe, -status, only five new items would 
satisfy you: 
-aktion (a REAL noun from "akti"), -resultat, -(t)ori, -(t)if, and 
maybe -(e)nt for a present participle. 

Put these five into the Core-dictionary, with the remark that they are 
not original and with the advice possibly not to use them, and let the 
language users do what they want. 

I wonder, whether it would help, damage or destroy Glosa.

>  > No. Please do not accuse me of making a new language project.

> You would prefer a language between Occidental (and others) and Glosa.

NO!!!!!, not a new language! We have enough right now.
Again: use existing IALs, but do not remain chained to them.

> Prefixes, suffixes and so on or pidgin/creole?

I would prefer P/C but recently it seems incontestable
that the authors imported all the prefixes and many suffixes.
European languages do creolize nicely, and we have no other
example of an IAL of this type. (Lingua Franca Nova has
almost nothing in common with the real LF.)

> If Glosa would have suffixes, it would get
> part-of-speech-markers (remember: Interglossa had ones!).

No, p.o.s. markers are superfluous, and that is why linguists
laugh at Esperanto and Ido. Real languages have a set of affixes
that inherently define p.o.s., e.g. in "electr-ic, terrif-ic"
the -IC is *an* adjectival suffix, not the *only* one.

But if Glosa were to eliminate all euro-suffixes, their
functions would be transferred to prefixed compounds.
De Wahl suggested that will eventually happen in eurolangs.
So, why not a Glosa that accelerates this development?

> And then the complete language would come into danger.  ...?
> Perhaps "halfway between" is gold?

Try using it! If it remains halfway, and is used, something good
might happen. But I doubt it. Currently, I can't stop amid each
sentence to convert a natural -IC suffix to a compound.

> Now I would say, it was quite successful, the dictionary is useful,

Yes, the first real accomplishment I've seen here. Kudos!

> When we allow all Romanic and Greek words, then a Spaniard speaks 
> Spanish and claims to speek Glosa, also the Italian, the Brazilian, 
> the French and the Greek.  And all are right!  And I ---- understand 
> none of them.

Because they used the non-international words. They are therefore wrong.

> Learning only 10 words per day needs discipline, even if the words are 
> international.  

There is no time for adults to learn a second language
that way. The words must be known to them within their
native language. And they are! In one weekend you teach
how to recognize the international words they already know.
Vocabulary is then a solved problem.

> ==> A vocabulary restriction is necessary.

But impossible. Tomorrow a new international word is born.
Everybody uses it except adherents of some religious IAL.

An IAL is *not* a language for children, and should not be
taught in schools; only the great cultural languages should be.
An IAL is for *adults*, who already have well-learned their native lang.
It would be a disaster, a culture-cide, a fanatical vandalism,
to attempt to replace our natural languages with any IAL.

> I would say: The Glosa authors tried all.

Yes, and improved Interglossa greatly, with interesting results.
It just isn't ready as an IAL, without an additional huge input
from the user's imagination. It needs more work, and could be fixed
in several different ways. The remaining author must give the direction.

> inconsistencies in the dictionary resulting from a missing system.

No dictionary can hold all the words of any language,
there must be a system. Every natural lang has such a system,
but lacks sufficient regularity to be easily learned.

> They tried a restricted vocabulary (Glosa 1000) and allowed every
> other Latin/Greek/scientific (and really Italian!) word simultanously
> as "Mega Glosa".

Oh. Well, something more has to be done now, because it's a mess.

> Well, hmm.

Marcel Springer wrote:
> 
> For Charles, a "cheap" way to Occideglossa:

OK, we will play!

> with the remark that they are
> not original and with the advice possibly not to use them, and let the
> language users do what they want.

I only feel justified in using what is *already* present in Glosa.
The Euro-Glossa exists in those crypto-suffixes. For a more interesting
Creolo-Glosa: All the cryptosuffixes are ejected, along with the ugly
apriori -po -bo set. Only word-compounding is allowed:

Occ:    Crypto:      Creolo:      English:
====    ========     =======      ===========================
-ion    -tio         -akti        deverbal abstract noun, action
-or     -ero, -ra?   -homi, -uti  deverbal agentive noun
-ori    -ori         sista-?      deverbal adj., consistent with
-iv     -i, -ivi     pote-        deverbal adj., able/likely to
-ura    -ura, -ur-   -resulta?    deverbal concrete noun, result
-t      -t-, -d-?    fini-        participle, past/passive
-nt     -nt-, -nd-?  dura-        participle, present/active

This is good legal effective official Glosa, actually,
both the Crypto and Creolo columns are in the dictionary.
Only a radical reform-purge-inquisition can remove them!

I know I could use Crypto, because I did already in my experiment
several days ago. Crypto looks like all the other interlingues
and mixes well, i.e. is comprehensible without study. Only the
agentive nouns are a problem, and could be fixed somehow.
But the world has no need for Crypto-Glosa when better IALs exist.

Creolo is the truer spirit of Interglossa/Glosa, IMO.
And I know it would work, because other P/C langs do.
Over time the 3-syllabic compounders would be simplified,
as happened rapidly with the Chinook Jargon. My ideal for
Glosa would be all bi-syllabic roots and no affixes,
all roots compoundable in a systematic and productive way.
Until last month I thought the authors intended such, and
simply had not finished cleaning up the mess. I wish they
(Wendy) would direct us and others to perfect Creolo-Glosa.
