*   Friends,
    Nice to hear Jay's comments.  Yes, I'd say the Glosa authors were
trying to have it both ways: they made Glosa creole-like with a simply
derived vocabulary, and then they planned for it to be easy to learn with
virtually no morphological grammar.
    The 'Head Final' SVO sentence structure seems to be working quite well,
with the only deficiency worrying me being the lack of further "semantic",
hyphenated suffixes.  This refers to the "generic terms". Allowing only
eigteen two-letter, abbreviated semantic suffixes does seem too few for
civilised conversation; Paul Bartlett mentioned this some time ago,
forshadowing the possible introduction of more , and probably longer,
semantic affixes.  And these have sneaked into Glosa with
~-abili~, ~-ismo~, ~logi~, etc.  However, Paul dislikes the hyphen, because
it has no sound attached, and cannot be pronounced: my belief is that the
hyphen separates discrete words and word abbrevitions, and  assists the
reader etymologically and the computer, symbolically .. while preventing
the pronunciations of the elements of a compound from interfering with
one-another.

   We probably need some more "generic terms."

Saluta,

Robin Gaskell

*   So, I appreciate Jay's giving me this opportunity to re-inforce a
difference between Glosa and some of the other Interlanguages.

    Glosa was perceived of as a whole language, in itself.  The idea being
that, as well as having the qualities listed, in the paragraph above, it
was presented to be a "comprehensive" language, with a life of its own.
    During the time that I was 'retelling', not 'translating', _The Three
Bears_, I got a shock when I reached the stage that, instead of stumbling
to make Glosa work, I found that the language, itself, was carrying me
along.  On reflection, I realised that I was no longer breathing life into
Glosa, but, instead, it was running ahead of me and inspiring my thoughts.
 
    I had expected to take much longer, to reach such a stage, with a
language that was being shaped by being hewn out of the 'communication
stream' rather than by being absorbed 'through immersion.'   It was at this
stage that I discovered Glosa really had a life of its own.

    On further reflection, I have found that my thinking on, and usage of,
English has changed - as a result of my discoveries about language through
thinking about Glosa.  Such prognostications have led me to make
suggestions that, to develop fluency, one should aim at "thinking in
Glosa," and that Glosa, like the 'natural' languages, is congruent with
"the language of thought."

    And one factor, of the Glosalist experience, that has worried me as a
language researcher, is the small number of subscribers, who have actually
used Glosa to produce writing of over one paragraph, in length.  I greatly
enjoyed reading Bill Patterson's translation of "The Wolf," and was very
pleased that others were drawn into working on this translation.  Also, I
am glad to see, of late, a number of e-mail contributions in Glosa.  It
does however, definitely help me - in my research - to compare the Glosa
with an appended English-language 'translation.'

    Which reminds me to ask: how many Glosalist-pe are not venturing to
write in Glosa for fear of making 'errors'; and, how many contributors
would not like 'corrections' to their use of Glosa published on the List?
    This is a tricky point, with Ron gone, and Wendy currently not on the
Net, I offer suggestions for others who are learning to use Glosa.  So I
would make some suggestions and ask some questions.  Subscribers might
respond to the following statements on the Glosalist or directly to me:-
Yes . No. ?
 ___|___|___  1. I think in Glosa.
 ___|___|___  2. Irregularities in the vocabulary prevent me from writing
                   in Glosa.
 ___|___|___  3. A lack of clear-cut guidelines on syntax prevent me from
                   writing in Glosa.
 ___|___|___  4. I do write in Glosa and am confident that I am using
                   standardised sentence form.
 ___|___|___  5. I do write in Glosa, but am in a state of subjective
                   uncertainty over my usage.  
 ___|___|___  6. As far as I know, my Glosa usage is correct, but I could
                   be in error on some points.
 ___|___|___  7. Sometimes when attempting to use Glosa, I find that there
                   are some ideas I feel unable to express in Glosa. 
 ___|___|___  8. A better dictionary is needed before I can feel happy in
                   attempting to use Glosa.
 ___|___|___  9. An instruction manual is needed before I can feel happy
                   in attempting to use Glosa.
 ___|___|___ 10. A basic grammar book will improve my use of Glosa.
 ___|___|___ 11. A basic grammar book is needed before I can feel happy in 
                   attempting to use Glosa.
 ___|___|___ 12. I can understand the structure of the language through
                   observation of printed Glosa texts.
 ___|___|    13. There are aspects of the language I seek further
                   information on: ______________________________________
                   ______________________________________________________

** When filling in this table, and selecting the "?" column, you might wish
to venture a percentage value, to indicate what percentage of the statement
is true for you.
## If you wish to complete the table, but do not want your response
included in an overall assesment - on the List - place a cross here |___|. 

   Friends, This is the first time I have asked for direct feedback from
you: perhaps it is well overdue; however, with the anonymity of the
Internet, some might feel that such questioning is an invasion of 
privacy.  By way of explanation, I come from an age before the word
"privacy" was generally current in the language; also, in the dim distant
past, when I joined the race, calling a "spade a spade" was a sign of
integrity.  Attempting to be 'modern,' I do not wish to force anyone to do
anything they do not want to do, nor do I wish to invade anyone's privacy;
however, in seeking the truth upon which science is supposed to be based,  
I would encourage all Glosalist-pe to send in a response, either privately,
or publicly.

Gracia,

Robin Gaskell

From: Charles <root{at}catty{dot}com>

> I'd say the Glosa authors were
> trying to have it both ways: they made Glosa creole-like with a simply
> derived vocabulary, and then they planned for it to be easy to learn with
> virtually no morphological grammar.

There either are affixes or not; examination of the
vocab proves that there are both prefixes and suffixes.
Beginners only avoid them for a while, not for long,
because they need to make certain distinctions:
credible vs. credulous, believed vs. believing,
believe vs. belief, believer vs. politician, etc.

This can be accomplished either by compounds or suffixes,
but they must be productive, i.e. usable spontaneously
rather than by consulting a dictionary. This requires a
real system, which is not clearly visible to me in Glosa.
"Glosa has no grammar" is not sounding so great anymore.
It looks to me like the authors just haven't finished it.

I don't know whether to use crypto-suffixes or head-last
compounding, and I doubt they could ever mesh well;
English does not use compounding for such things:
-able, -ive, -ed, -ing, -ion, -er, -ee, etc.
Glosa should add similar true suffixes rather than the
rather silly artificial -bo -po generics, or else state
clearly what compounds to use (pote-kredi, du-kredi, etc??).
Until then I don't expect to see people writing much in it.

>In "The Loom of Language" by Frederick Bodmer (and edited by Lancelot

>flexione]
>
>"Interlingua has NO mobile derivative affixes to juggle with. It is wholly
>analytical, like Chinese or, we might almost add, Anglo-American. What
>prefixes and suffixes remain stick firmly to the Latin or Greek loan-word
>with all their diversity of meaning, contradictions and obscurities in
>English, French, or Spanish usage."

>attempted analysis of Glosa words into "meaningful" elements!

*   Nick, please spell out for me what is meant by this, with a small
number of examples.

    Are you talking about the tendency to analyse the lexical components of
original Greek and latin roots?  Personally, I find the etymological
approach handy - to help me understand the 'flavour' of the original
source-words.  However, I do tend to think that the final forms of the
words in the derivative national languages have great linguistic value, and
that such syntheses should not be ^cracked open^ to retrieve the small
lexical seeds within .. for the purpose of further sythetic recombination.
    This does not cut across the idea of 'abbreviation', by which the
simplest functional form of a word is derived, often for the purpose of use
in compound formation. 
EG.  KINE  -->  KI ...--> KI-AB

Saluta,

Robin Gaskell

Robin, that is exactly my point! You've illustrated it quite
well. I agree that there comes a thresh-hold to be crossed
at some point in a language learners experience when the
language is no mere translation or relexing of the thought
but a true expression of thought. I agree to some extent with
the idea of Sapir-Whorf that language can influence thought,
but I would not agree to the extreme they bring their conclusions,
so is my opinion, but I do believe that when thought is purely
expressed in a language, this fluent expression, is a great
step in a learners advancement in the target language. Some
people never reach that stage. In the case of some interlinguists
perennial tweaking only leads to much talk and experimentation
but they seem to never make the step to fluent expression of
thoughts. The continual tweaking has its fault in that the
changes prevent the full apprehension of patterns needed to
express thoughts fluently.

Since,
Jay B.

To: <glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au>

From: Jay Bowks <jjbowks{at}adam{dot}cheshire{dot}net>

QUESTIONNAIRE ANSWERS FOR JAY BOWKS

> 1. I think in Glosa.
Once I get going on a translation exercise or
start writing my notes to this list in Glosa.
I find it easier to keep my word-list open just
in case memory fails me though.

> 2. Irregularities in the vocabulary prevent me from writing in Glosa.
No, irregularities are part of all languages.

> 3. A lack of clear-cut guidelines on syntax prevent me from writing in Glosa.
No but... The mechanics of Glosa afford a sample syntax
formula that one can imitate. But a grammar
book that examines these would be helpful for
some.

> 4. I do write in Glosa and am confident that I am using standardised sentence
form.
Yes. As long as I stick to the wordlists and the
mechanics I know it's good enough for use.

> 5. I do write in Glosa, but am in a state of subjective uncertainty over my
usage.
Not uncertain. I write Glosa when I feel up to
it and I have my wordlists and sample sentences
handy for reference.

> 6. As far as I know, my Glosa usage is correct, but I could be in error on
some points.
Yes, I might make errors, that's why I depend
on the wordlists and samples.

> 7. Sometimes when attempting to use Glosa, I find that there
> are some ideas I feel unable to express in Glosa.
Yes, at times, then I try re-expressing the thought
in other words. This is something that happens to me
in several languages. It is a skill to master, as I
see it. "Circumlocution" talking about the object using
other words which are familiar to you.

> 8. A better dictionary is needed before I can feel happy in attempting to use
Glosa.
Maybe. A better dictionary would help spread Glosa's
use... Something like a "Teach Yourself: Glosa" book
with a glossary included.

> 9. An instruction manual is needed before I can feel happy
> in attempting to use Glosa.
No, one can start with what is found right now on the
net. But a manual like I mention above would definitely
help spread Glosa to new speakers all over.

> 10. A basic grammar book will improve my use of Glosa
Yes, a grammar primer with exercises would definitely
give me some practice of the language so this would help.

> 11. A basic grammar book is needed before I can feel
> happy in attempting to use Glosa.
Not really. I'm happy right now. But I'd be delighted to
purchase a manual like the one I mention above.
                   
> 12. I can understand the structure of the language through
> observation of printed Glosa texts.
Yes the Glosa mechanics samples offer an easily followed
set of patterns one can imitate.

> 13. There are aspects of the language I seek further information on:
Yes and No. On one hand the limited set of words in Glosa
serve as a means easy access to the language. The fact that
it has a limited vocabulary also hinders progress. A set
of standards in word formation would definitely improve
the language. For example any word ending in English
"-tion" could be used as "-cio" in Glosa. This would
of course change the language greatly and through the
idea of word economy out the window. But it would make
Glosa very approachable by Westerners who share this
international standardised set of Latin terms. Going
further with this development one could drop the ending
and have derived the root of the verb. If, for example...
communication = "komunikacio" ergo "komunika";
transportation = "transportacio" ergo "transporta".
But this would be a definite change of the language as
it is, perhaps too great to call it Glosa anymore, more
like Kosmo-Glosa and have Catty feeling all warm and
fuzzy inside. 

>14 I wish some folks would just develop their own auxlang
>and stop trying to change Glosa. (my addition)
Definitely! The fact that Glosa is good enough to use in
actuall exchanges of messages by students of it is reason
enough to consider it worthy of acceptance as it is.
That some folks wish to keep tweaking it goes against
the development of Glosa so far. It was a project with
a copyright by two individuals, it was developed and used
and it is good enough to use. Those that wish to can make
their own language project as they desire it and call it
something else.

Here is a sentence in English with some analysis (head of phrase in caps) :-

[subject] the slightLy fat MAN with the long (and) black hair /  [verb] 
quickly GAVE / [object] the blue BIRD / [INDIRECT OBJECT] to the thankful 
WOMAN.

Reduce words to stems, present tense stems, simplify ****ful

the slight.fat ......... did quick GIVE....... ........ the 
full-of-thank......... 

Look up words in dictionary

u pusi.obesi ANDRO ko u longi e melani triko / pa tako DONA / u kiano AVI / a 
u ple-de-gratia GINA.

Note - adverb.adjective "little fat" not "little man" and "fat man", (pusi e 
obesi) like "longi e melani"

Try replacing the English words in the example above and translating into 
Glosa. You must have a subject and a verb but the object and indirect object 
can be left out. They need not be noun phrases.

Be brave! Show us your results!

[As I wrote I asked Wendy about final vowels.  My examples have been 
SILVA/SILVI (forest) and ATRIA/ATRIO/ATRIU (hall).  Her answer is 
below.  Some points are very interesting, I think.  I will post the 
mentioned article from "Plu Glosa Nota" in a follow-up.]




Karo Marcel, 

  Place pardo, itera u-ci po-kron reakti.  Id uti mega energi pro mi 
de akti ali-ra plu-ci di!  Mi tenta gene pausa ex Glosa; sed plu grama 
dura veni; sura mi tako reakti a plu neo qestio-grama e plu bibli 
demanda; sed ne este sati dina te re-proto publika diskursi de Glosa 
alo dice de Ron alo Glosa per telefona; mi kade ad in plu lakrima!  Ne 
es facili de es u sensativi-pe.  Anti-co, mi usuali es dina-pe; e sura 
mi fu gene repara. 

  Mi matri es no-sani (osteoartriti e Parkinson es bi duce pato) e 
pende ex mi.  Pre tri setimana fe pa kade in via epi betona. 

  Mi inklude PGN 37.  Kausa id dona info de fini vokali.  Ron ne pa 
pensi id es fo gravi-ra; id es pro mi tem faci plu kruci-verba!  Fini 
vokali ne es ge-nexu ko Latin alo Greko gramatika.  "Glosa 6000" bibli 
1992 pa gene grafo fo tako e per neo puta-me; ka-co, posi fini vokali 
posi ne es boni elekti.  Na pa akordo ko plu fini vokali in Central 
Glosa.  Probabli ATRIU gene uti te evita konfusi ko atro (black).  
Sometimes final vowel is left out ATR- could then mean black or hall.  
SILVA as in PennsylvAnia but SILVi as in Silviculture.  Ron suggested 
both could be used.  If choice necessary to have only one, choose the 
most common, choose the most common, which would probably be your 
suggestion of SILVA, as this occurs in plant + insect names etc. 

  PGN 81-82, 83 posi pa tena varita de plu ortografo.  Ron pa habe 
86 anua; an menta pa es fo boni pro u-la eva, qe?  An pa spende poli 
hora stude puta-me e Glosa ergo; an pa habe ma energi de ali-pe mi 
ski!

  Fu-tem mi nece gene Glosa lexi-lista ma stabili e difusi Glosa a 
poli-pe.  Mi es hedo; na difusi Glosa info per puta-me; place este 
libe de difusi ali-ra ex "PGN", "Sko-Glosa" alo plu bibli per u-ci 
mode; sed place deklara u fonta de ali ge-uti info.  Na nece kontinu 
u splendi ergo de Hogben e Clark.

  Mega gratia de tu stimula e auxi; mi fo valu tu persisti.

  Poli ami saluta 

  ex Wendy.

Well, final vowels were not given much importance by either
Ron or Wendy, according to the other message you posted.
So, it is as we surmised, and they are very easily repaired:
the rule is that they don't matter (are in "free variation")
in most cases, therefore need not be memorized.

We need to account for the few problem cases where they conflict,
that's all. But if we (thee? not me) happen to fix the finals
in an etymologically improved fashion, that can't hurt anyone's
feelings, and it can improve Glosa greatly and cheaply. Example:

15      animala      animal
234     animali      animal, beast
5       animaliza    brutalize

OK, I see Latin "animalis" as an adjectival form,
so -i is very plausible. If the Glosa word is to function
as verb/noun/adjective, maybe -i is the only good choice.

12345   ANIMALI      animal, beast, brute, brutal, brutalize

We could have fun going through the whole vocabulary.
Don't despair, recognizing a problem is the first step
toward solving it. Only denial or apathy fails utterly.

There are approximately 6848 Glosa words (including
spelling variants). The number of words containing
each letter, and their percentages:

y       2       .000

W and Y are really just errors or jokes, assuming
that whisk(e)y should really be spelled VISKI or UISKI.

A more serious reform would be to merge C K Q into one.
Another would be to merge Z into S, and eliminate X.
Why not eliminate H and J as well? Then we'd have:
ABCDEFG.I..LMNOP.RSTUV...., only 18 letters.
The H is not pronounced in modern Romance languages,
and J is pronounced I anyway in Glosa. So to complete
the intended fonetization of Glosa for global use, ...

Of course the final vowel problem must be solved: 
Glosa is in competition with other auxlangs.  Every unsolved problem 
  is a disadvantage in this competition. 
Differing final vowels are very problematic for a short hand system 
  and for computer translation. 
They are difficult to learn.  And vocabulary learning is hard work. 
  Ask a language teacher ;) ;) ;) ! 


An example to make clear what I mean (I think normally not necessary): 
To memorize the Latin word "via - way", you learn the root vi-, that 
is similar to the English, and the ending -a, which gives the 
beautiful imagination that via is female.  So you have to learn two 
things, both easy.  
For an auxlang only one would be best. 
But in Glosa you have to learn the root and the final vowel, again two 
things, but the final vowel does not give the imagination of a gender 
nor of anything else. 
A vowel on its own is abstract and difficult to memorize, similar to a 
number. 
A systematical chosen final vowel would help this. 

That is the problem and it is a problem.  Sure, we can and should use 
Glosa without taking final vowels too serious (see Wendy's letter), 
but that is only provisional (I hope).

    I am not feeling well this evening :-( so I won't try to respond in
Glosa.

On Mon, 2 Oct 2000, Marcel Springer wrote (excerpt):

> Of course the final vowel problem must be solved: 
> Glosa is in competition with other auxlangs.  Every unsolved problem 
>   is a disadvantage in this competition. 

    Yes.  When I first collated the wordlists for the Basic Reference
which I put up on the www (with A&C permission), I noticed the final
vowel problem for real: sometimes basically the same word on more than
one list with more than one final vowel, and sometimes two distinct
words differing only by the final vowel.

    I think the first issue can be solved simply by picking one of a
pair (or in at least one instance, one of a triplet) and using it
exclusively.  I myself am not convinced that it makes much difference
which one is chosen.  Of course, there is the position that one might
use the final vowel at least partially as a part of speech marker, in
the manner of Ido, Esperanto, Master, Suma, and many others.  Again, I
myself am not convinced that this is necessary.  If there is
standardization in the first instance, then I think that the second
issue more or less resolves itself.

    Contrary to an opinion that has been expressed here, I do not think
that all final vowels will degenerate into an undifferentiated mush. 
It is true that native English speakers tend to slur unstressed vowels,
but I do think that we can justifiably expect users of an auxiliary
language to expend at least a little effort if they want to be
understood.  I do not think that a constructed auxlang must always bow
to the habits of native English speakers.

> I do not think

> It is true that native English speakers tend to slur unstressed vowels,

[snipped etc]

Well, I retreat halfway from my mush hypothesis; we can certainly
distinguish MANU from MANE, or something like that. But there are
some terrible pairs like BALI BALE which really cannot be distinguished
in an unstressed syllable by *adult* learners internationally.
Those relatively few pairs can easily be fixed, no big deal.

There's still the significant difficulty of learning them, since
they follow no pattern. Best to use the etymologically correct vowel.
Again, a very easy reform that can't offend anyone but a lunatic.

Part-of-speech vowels are tempting, but I abandoned that Idoesque
idea a while back; they aren't sufficient anyway, because there are
more than 6 parts of speech, and many more derivatives than that.
The problem of word-derivation has no easy solution in Glosa,
other than random word-compounding e.g. "XXXX-ABILI".

From: Charles <root{at}catty{dot}com>

The best thing about Ogden's Basic English and Zamenhoff's
Esperanto (Linqvo Internacia) was that a single sheet of paper
could list the entire vocabulary, making it easy both to read
and write. This is only possible if the vocabulary is limited
to around 1000 roots, and a productive system of word
derivation is designed as part of the language.

Glosa's full vocab has generated much dissatisfaction:
inadequate to span the range of words needed for everyday use,
but too large for anybody to memorize or even comfortably study.
No way this can work for people lacking eurolang background.

People who can memorize 6000+ vocabularies can and do learn
French/Spanish/etc instead of any IAL. They amount to 5%
of the population. IALs are for the 95%. Only 2 strategies
can work; fortunately they can be used simultaneously:

1. concentrated 1000-root list
2. naturalistic open/infinite set

Out of the mass of 6543 or so official Glosa words,
there must be 1000 really good general words, suitable
for a solid-practical and easily-learnable basic vocab.
At random I pick LIG- ...

12345   lig     liga            bind, ligature, tether, tie
5       ligatur ligatura        book-binding
4       lign    karbo ligni     charcoal
245     lign    ligni           timber, wood
4       lign    ligni-pe        carpenter
4       lign    tekto ligni     timber
5       ligr    ligro           baneful

That's basically 7 terms, 3 roots (LIGA, LIGNI, LIGRO).
Hmm ... the Occidental Radicarium has only these 2:
"LIGAR = to bind" and "LIGNE = wood". Kennedy's book
"Word Stems" lists the same 2, with these derivatives:
ligament, ligature, alligation, league, oblige;
ligneous, ligniferous, lignite, lignumvitae.
Of course there are infinitely many more. Well,
what do they know? Let's try the Novial Lexike:

ligamente FED, D Gelenkband. 

lige F ligue, E league, D Liga, Bund, Bündnis
| -ga F lier, E bind, attach, D (fest)binden, zusammenbinden
| -gostreke F trait d'union, E hyphen, D Bindestrich. 

ligne F bois (matière), E wood (material), D Holz
| -naje F charpente, E woodwork, D Holzwerk
| -natri. 

Who cares what Otto Jesperson says?? We'll ask Dr. Gode:

liga ligamento ligamentose ligamine ligar ligatura
ligni-cole lignificar lignification ligni-forme
lignina lignite ligno lignose ligure
Liguria ligus- ligustico ligustro

Sorry I asked ... Anyway, it looks like we stumbled onto
a couple of productive internationally known roots here.
If we kept only the 2/7ths of the Glosa words which are
equally productive and international, that would be cool!

Users would still be at a loss for a system (simple pattern)
to help them derive all those derivatives, but such could
EVOLVE through real-LIVE usage.

Not only that, but these international words are recognizable
with very little study, to over 2 billion busy people today.
It would also put the language teachers out of business.

[English seqe Glosa] 

Karo Alexander, 

  Fo boni; tu akti ta mega ergo.  Mega gratia!!!

  Nu mi adi plu "G"-marka (marka de plu verba ko Heleni origi) ad u 
"Glosa Internet Dictionary" uti u bibli "Glosa 6000".  Mi pa puta; u 
6000-lista pa gene kompleti loka in GID pre-tem.  Sed tem mi adi plu 
"G"; mi mali-fortuna detekti plu ero in plu datu.  E poli English 
semani-verba ne es la.  Na feno debi verifi holo 6000-lista e ne solo 
plu G-verba. 

  Pro tu ergo, mi bali u lista ko ge-muta ra ad tu.  Mi spe; id auxi e 
tu ne lose hedo.  Tem mi pa fini plu 6000-G; mi maxi tako fu bali u 
holo neo GID a tu. 

  Maxi nume de plu problema es in 6000-verba.  Plu verba ko "1" e 
"++" habe minus ero.  Si tu proto translati plu-ci; tu gene u ma 
funktio verba-lista ma tosto pluso.  So mi pa volu akti ko u Deutsch 
versio; sed mi ne pa detekti tem pro u-ci ergo pre-nu. 

Saluta - Marcel 

[Dear Alexander, 
  Great that you do so much work.  Thank you!!! 
  At the moment I am adding some "G"-marks (marks for words with Greek 
origin) with help of the book "Glosa 6000" to the Internet Dictionary. 
I thought, the 6000-list is completely inserted already.  But while 
adding "G"s I unfortunately found some errors in the data.  And a lot 
of English meanings are missing.  It seems necessary that the complete 
6000-list will be checked and not only the G-words. 
  For your work I send a list with the done corrections.  I hope it 
helps and does not lessen your motivation.  When I am through the 
6000-Gs I send an dictionary update to you as soon as possible. 
  The problems are mainly in the 6000-words.  The words with "1" and 
"++" are more stable.  When you take these words first, you will also 
get an useful dictionary earlier.  So I wanted to do with the German 
version, but I did not find time for this work yet. ]

Karo Robin, Marcel e Alex
Ma de Kroma In Glosa:-

So na habe un amonta de foto ab zero (melani) a face tiflo, un unda alti, un 
unda longi, puri kroma e konfusi kroma ab zero, in puri a maxi,  in alba.

Il ne es freqe na vide veri puri kroma, melano, alba alo polio. Plu puri 
kroma posi es mixa kon alba e pote es ge  dice es foto alo ko melano e es 
skoto.

Exampla:- Na habe plu defini:- foto rubi, skoto kiano e purpura polio. 
Anti-co, uno de plu skoto kroma habe un idio nima. Mo de plu-ci es "bruno" ka 
id ne feno es skoto orange.
 
MI pa uti u grafo de "Kroma" te face ma brevi Internet Glosa Dictionary ka, 
alterna id es fo boni, il es multi proxi itera etc.     gold_dust e gold-dust
Vice u face de pan lexiko, mi grafo un artikula, verifi ko IGD e  marka u-la 
verba qe mi posi fu ne uti. Mi nu habe u lexiko qi mi marka ko "$" =ok, "£" 
=ne ok, "?" =posi uti ko hetera proxi semani. Alex posi trovi u-la metodi sio 
auxi an.
Mi fu loka plu-ci epi u mi web pagina.....
Plu gratia de Marcel info de Ostwald e plu hetera auxi komenta de Robin e plu 
ami.
saluta
syd

A guy on another list posted these links, which are
nothing new but still are of great interest ...

> http://www.sys.uea.ac.uk/~jrk/conlang.dir/Speedwords.overview

> http://www.sys.uea.ac.uk/~jrk/conlang.dir/Speedwords.dict

... because it suddenly occurs to me that this list
of 493 "concepts" based on Roget's, like Glosa's vocab
reportedly was too, could be re-translated directly
back into Glosa to ensure they are really in there.

Speedwords also has a true system of derivation, which
theoretically generates something like 20,000 words total.
Glosa lacks that, still, but why not add it? Might be
a fun/instructive exercise just to try.

[Qo-mode mi pa promise; mi nu bali u artikla de jurnali "Plu Glosa
Nota" nume 37.  Id dona info de plu fini-vokali.  Id pa gene grafo
pro responde ad u lekto-pe-grama mi ne fu bali.  Penite de plu mi
tipo-ero.  "subseqUe" e "qUerkus" posi es ur-ero, sed posi kausa
PGN 37 habe paleo Glosa?  Pluso u posi de uti Français voci pro
Français verba pa dona interese ad mi.  Saluta - Marcel.]


"
MEGA-GLOSA, BUT ...
===================

As regards your first suggestion.  We agree that to sell Glosa to
bodies such as EEC, UN, UNESCO etc. MEGA-GLOSA, a large vocabulary is
essential.  Scientists, literary people and politicians require it.

We however insist that GLOSA 1000 must remain the Centre, the Heart of
Glosa.  Glosa is a truly International Auxiliary Language.  It will
appeal to the motivated Third World artisan only if it is simple to
learn and accurate, and able to deal with all kinds of information
exchange.  Glosa will not be allowed to fall into the trap of becoming
only a holiday language for wealthy people of the industrialized
nations.  The world will never be healthily united until accurate
information is readily available to everyone everywhere, and everybody
in the world has enough to eat, good shelter and a good-allround
education - an education for living not merely for earning a living.
The world has now the means (but not yet the will) to bring all this
about quickly and thoroughly.

Europeans are used to large vocabularies, which can contribute to mis-
understandings not only between nations but also between classes.  We
hope that although perhaps enjoying the variety and freedom of Mega
Glosa people will at the same time work their way up to Central
Glosa 1000.

Below we make some provisional suggestions for forming a Mega
Vocabulary.  Glosa 6000 by the way has all the information for forming
a truly enormous vocabulary.  We shall bring out a Mega Glosa as soon
as possible.



FINDING THE ROOT
================

All you have to do to form your own MegaGlosa is to be able to
recognize a Latin and Greek root.  Most of the common ones will be
listed in Glosa 1000, the others will be in Glosa 6000.  In any long
word of classical origin there may be ...

        Prefix - root - suffix.
   Eg.  SUPER     FLU     OUS

Remember Glosa has no parts of speech; and any Glosa word can act as
any part of speech.  Because the suffix is usually concerned with this
kind of information, whether the word is verb, noun, adjective or
adverb it is usually superfluous for Glosa and can be removed.

If the Prefix is one with a distinct meaning i. e. one of the
35 listed in PGN 36 this must be retained as it contributes to
meaning, to information.  So generalizing;

   Word minus suffix = Prefix + root.

                       the word you want.
In the above example the root is FLU, to flow, SUPER over; therefore
SUPERFLU, overflow.  In a way forming a Mega Glosa Vocabulary involves
'tail-chopping'.



POINTS TO NOTE
==============

Many verbs of Latin origin end in -ate.  All you have to do here is
knock off the -te.  confiscate becomes KONFISKA.

Always substitute K for hard Latin c.  So canine becomes KANI, feline
FELI.

Some words ending -age are of French origin.  These can be kept giving
MESAGE, FOLIAGE.

No double letters in Glosa, except on a few occasions where a
well-trilled r may have a good echoic effect.  Some examples;

 English        GLOSA
 delicious      DELICI        degenerate  DEGENERA
 industrialize  INDUSTRI      subsequent  SUBSEQUE
 contortion     KONTORTI      population  POPULA

In 99 % of all cases this simple method will work perfectly, but
occasionally some part of the suffix may be found useful and can be
retained.

Words ending -ism  add -o.   REALISMO.  KOMUNISMO.
Words ending -ist  add -i.   REALISTI.  FATALISTI.
Words ending -ment add -a.   PARLAMENTA.  MOVIMENTA.

Biological and medical terms remain unchanged; OAKTREE is QUERKUS.
K can be substituted for Latin C.  Musical terms remain unchanged,
many of these were listed in PGN 16.  Eg. KRESCENDO, FORTISIMO,
DIMUNENDO, ACELERANDO.  French endings like -age above should be
given the French pronounciation.



THE TWO PARTS OF THE LATIN VERB
===============================

Another possibility of variety arises from the fact that the Latin
verb has two parts, each of which gives rise to great numbers of
Euro-verbs.  Eg;
  to see         infinitive       VIDE  as in VIDEO
                 past participle  VISum as in VISion.
So for GLOSA 'to see' can be rendered by VIDE or VISI.  Other
examples;
  join together  i.               NEKT  as in conNECT
                 pp.              NEXU  as in NEXUs.
  to lead        i.               DUCE  as in reDUCE
                 pp.              DUCT  as in conDUCT.



WHEN IS A WORD INTERNATIONAL
============================

In PGN 35 there was an article on PACTERM, Pan-African-Centre for
TERMinology, centredin Addis Ababa.  All the participants at a recent
seminar in Ethiopia agreed that a term should be recognized as
international when it appeared in French, German, Russian and English.
We use a very large German-Russian Dictionary published in Moscow by
A. A. Lepinga & Straxhovoi.

See also, the article about INFOTERM in this issue.



KOSMOPOLITAN GREEK
==================

It has been said that if all the words of Greek origin were suddenly
removed from the world's dictionaries all intelligent conversation
would come to an end.  Nowadays scientists turn almost exclusively to
Greek for new terminology.  Three ways by which you can recognize
words of Greek origin.

1) There are many double consonants. Eg;
   PSYCHOLOGY, CATARRH, RHYTHM, THEME, ARCHITECT, HYPHEN, PNEUMONIA.
2) There are many diphthongs; Eg
   EUPHONY, HAEMOGLOBIN
3) All those words in which ch is pronounced like a k.  Eg;
   ARCHITECT, CHARACTER.

The Greek words are not quite so familiar yet as the Latin, but they
are daily becoming ever more so.  TELE-SCOPE, SYMBOL, SYMPTOM,
SYMPHONY are all Greek, and they never have undergone any changes.
They are however far more international than the Latin.  They
probably make up a half of Glosa 6000; and the Advanced Glosa
Dictionary is almost entirely Greek.

"

> a victim of English's ridiculous spelling

I used to think that way, but now I think it's only
the English pronunciation that is ridiculous.
Same for French. Our archaic pre-sound-shift spelling
preserves all the beautiful Greco-Latin derivatives.

Glosa was originally based on these derivatives,
but the relationship was lost by a naive and misguided
"fonetic" spelling. There are many people in Europe
who cannot speak or understand English *speech*, but
can read/write it very acceptably because of these
cognate words and their formal book-study.

Occidental was based on "archaic" etymological spelling,
which remains recognizable across most European languages
today in derivative/scientific words. This is the true
international vocabulary, natural and non-apriori.

So I recommend that English/French/Spanish all return
to a truer etymological spelling, and adjust their
pronunciation to fit the writing, not the reverse!
If that were done, we would find that 50% of the words
are identical, and not need any artificial interlanguage.
This E-F-S language that already exists in writing
covers 4 of the 7 continents and half the population ...

Glosa should join that party, in its next revision.

From: Charles <charles{at}catty{dot}com>

Marcel Springer wrote:

> MEGA-GLOSA, BUT ...

Nice polemic, good thought.

> Europeans are used to large vocabularies

Those vocabularies are built using relatively few
(5000) roots and a set of derivational affixes.
There is a natural system to it, somewhat irregular.
The task of a designed language should be to identify
the roots, spell them in the most internationally
recognizable fashion, and provide a regular set of affixes.

> All you have to do to form your own MegaGlosa

Dangerous idea, I like it.

> Many verbs of Latin origin end in -ate.

Also, -ion, -ive, -ous, -ary, -ory, -ble, -bly, -ure,
and about 200 others. In Spanish, same story.

> Always substitute K for hard Latin c.

Big mistake, because it breaks the derivational families,
e.g. FACt/FACile conDUCive/DUCtile ... myriads more.
Same for soft-G. Better to throw out K and Q both.
And Z and X and W and maybe Y. And H. But J may be useful.

> Some words ending -age are of French origin.  These can be kept giving
> MESAGE, FOLIAGE.

Latin, -aticus; present in every European language as
-age and related -agie but spelled often with J.

> No double letters in Glosa

I think that's also a mistake: "ad + cept = ac-cept",
"in + rigare = irrigate". Anything that disguises etymology
also prevents recognition and is evil.

> Words ending -ism  add -o.   REALISMO.  KOMUNISMO.
> Words ending -ist  add -i.   REALISTI.  FATALISTI.
> Words ending -ment add -a.   PARLAMENTA.  MOVIMENTA.

You are being too reasonable, nobody will agree to that!
Anyway, better to leave out useless final vowels altogether,
maybe even use "realist, realism, realistic, realisar,
realisat, realisation, realisator, ..."

> Biological and medical terms remain unchanged

Scientific terms mutate more swiftly than the flu virus.
Nobody understands such jargon, why bother with it?

> Musical terms remain unchanged,

> Eg. KRESCENDO, FORTISIMO, DIMUNENDO, ACELERANDO.

Only 1% of the population will ever hear music of that type,
sad to say. It's just jargon anyway, doesn't belong in an IAL.

> THE TWO PARTS OF THE LATIN VERB

Very interesting stuff, but I doubt the Glosa authors
ever studied Latin or other interlanguages ... deaf ears.
Maybe I'm being too harsh, and I hope so. What we need is
a "Glosa Academy" to design version 3, if it is to survive.

> WHEN IS A WORD INTERNATIONAL

> international when it appeared in French, German, Russian and English.

German has not embraced the international roots, therefore
must be left out: there aren't many roots common to this set
of languages. Better is Spanish/English/French: there are
at least 20,000 words available, to be reduced to 5000 roots.
(Spanish could be augmented by Portuguese, to avoid ill-effects
of its unfortunate PL-->LL etc. sound changes.)

> KOSMOPOLITAN GREEK

> They are however far more international than the Latin.  They
> probably make up a half of Glosa 6000; and the Advanced Glosa
> Dictionary is almost entirely Greek.

I would eliminate Greek, but the other Glosa people won't.
Many reasons, but I'll leave that for elsewhen.

What a brave attempt by Marcel, to raise so many issues at once!
And they are mainly the essential ones. I hope Wendy will
take this *positively*, though I somehow don't expect so.
If 10 or so people decide to make a new reformed Glosa, though,
it could actually happen and might be very successful.

For myself, I can't quite see which way Glosa *should* evolve.
More like the naturalistic Novial/Occidental? More creolish
like Lingua Franca? More Greek like the Koine? Something else?
Whatever, I'd just like it to be more consistent and true
to its own principles, whatever they may be.

From: Charles <root{at}catty{dot}com>
Date: Sun, 22 Oct 2000 12:34:54 -0700


> re the spelling, it could be easier to get the standard pronunciation altered
> as gradually as charles suggests - a compromise might be possible whereby the
> spelling draws closer to the pronunciation and vice versa

When learning a natural language like French,
or in my case trying but not succeeding,
the major difficulty is that any variance from
Parisian usage is *wrong* and unacceptable.

But in an artificial bridge language,
there needs to be tolerance for variation.
All the users are new learners, and they must
feel free to speak/write without becoming
a target for criticism.

So any reasonably understandable spelling or
choice of words or etc should be encouraged as
necessarily *correct*. The only criterion for
proper usage is understandability. Good style
will be determined by popularity in actual use.

English went through a long period of unstandard
spelling, which did stop Shakespeare from using it
effectively, but stern schoolmasters were unhappy ...

The Glosa Internet Dictionary on my site has been updated again.  

Changes: 
- "G"-marks (for Greek words) have been added with the book 
    "Glosa 6000". 
- The English meanings of these Greek words have been compared, the 
    found errors corrected and missing English meanings added 
    (About 200 things.  A check of the complete Glosa-6000-data is 
    necessary.). 
- The alphabetical sorting has been improved. 

The corrections are protocoled in 
  www.tu-harburg.de/~smms1406/gidhist.txt.gz . 
Lines 1800 to 1986 may be interesting for Alexander, Robin and all 
users of Robin's GLOSA.ALL-file.  Because GLOSA.ALL has been one of 
the source files for the Internet Dictionary, a lot of the found 
Dictionary's errors are in GLOSA.ALL, too.  I posted the examples A to 
H in Glosalist 00-10-04 already. 

I sent a paper copy of the dictionary to Wendy Ashby.  

URLs as before.  Place visita.  Saluta Marcel. 
 ( www.tu-harburg.de/~smms1406/glosae.htm ,     my Glosa webpage

00-08-04 e 00-09-30).  Nu fe feno retro e kontinu poko ergo pro Glosa. 
  ("Inter-tem, ko tu auxi e gentili stimula mi re-proto Glosa aktivi; 
   pro u-ci, mega gratia!") 
Klu fe grafo; fe ma volu ergo Glosa homo holo-tem-ergo, sed fe nece 
merito valuta pro bio.

www.tu-harburg.de/~smms1406/gsimsyn.htm ); kausa mi puta; Glosa

bi pagina ple de mega valu nota a plu ra in lista.  Mi spe, mi fu

And I hope to get more.

Suggestions to reduce the amount of words in Core are always welcome.  
But your both examples are not right.  "zefiro  west wind" is only in 
Literary, not in Core.  And "loko" is in Core, "topo" not, although 
there is a difference, as Nick explained recently:  "loko" is 
place/area, "topo" is place/point.  See also PGN 71, p. 4.

Sydpidd{at}aol{dot}com wrote:

> I am going through with the help of programs I've
> cobbled together  , to make a smaller pocket sized version of words that I
> actually use. I'm doing the same with as much of the glosalist glosa too. We
> are both doing different but useful work - we need the full one and also
> smaller ones from it
> I am going to put together a web page with lots of glosa as glosalist seems
> to be mostly english which defeats the list's object

These are great ideas, and your work will *not* be wasted.
In discussions on the Occidental lists, I've seen an odd effect:
people benefit more from making their own word lists than
from having a big thick official dictionary.

Dictionaries aren't very readable, so they don't speed-up
language acquisition, and the sheer mass of 6000 entries only
convinces people that they can never hope to master the language.
Glosa's shorter vocab and categorized lists are a big help.
Still, the ideal hasn't been reached (whatever that is).

A linguist friend of mine can quickly learn almost any language,
to a passable and usable degree, by translating his own list
of approximately 1500 essential words. I only know I can *not*
memorize over a thousand vocabulary items ...

This led me to the concept of the already-existing international
vocabulary based on Greco-Latin, as used in several well-known IALs.
European-language speakers (adult, literate) are already familiar
with these words or their cognate forms, etc etc.

In reading Glosa I have trouble with many of the words, some vaguely
recognizeable but ambiguous, others just completely unfamiliar.
Writing is easier, paradoxically, but seems almost like a code.
Not enough vocab, yet too much. Hence my dissatisfaction.
But maybe it works better for other people, or non-Euros.

Speculation follows ...

My own idea would be to take the super-productive verb roots
as discussed earlier, and try to build an entire vocab from them.
The basic ("light") verbs such as BE/HAVE/DO would be included
along with a few that have no super-productive equivalent.

Those (approximately) 100 verb-roots would be *all* ...
Learnable in a single weekend, easy to print on a single page.
Similarly, basic adjectives and adverbs would be defined,
just a limited set, e.g. things like "up" "good" "many".
Then a group of general-category nouns must be added, enough
for general discourse. Roughly then, 500 words in total.

Specific discussions would incorporate other words from the
international air, but not all of those words need to be listed
in an official dictionary, especially since they change so fast.
Today we need "vote" and "snippy", tomorrow something else.

The goal would be a list that can be learned and used easily and
most rapidly by an average adult who has some exposure to some
European language. Maybe it would work for Arabic, Turkish,
or some other language speakers as well. Anyway, it could
actually *work* ... A language for "eternal beginners" (like
Esperanto) is worse than useless.

I like Occidental well enough, but if Glosa can beat it
(by being easier or faster to learn by more people), great!
Or if we can borrow good compatible features between IALs,
better yet. A short basic word list is an important element.

Dear Marcel
I seem to be working on a core dictionary from both top down and from bottom 
up. I'm getting a program to translate my english to glosa starting with the 
internet one (IND) and checking what it throws up. Often I get several glosa 
words and I check which I want and put the others in other files, this means 
that my own dictionary is getting tidied up and material that I don't want is 
pruned away. I am also going through glosa that is on glosalist and saving 
most of it. Doing this builds up some sort of core of words that are actually 
in use rather than slaving through a long long dictionary. My results I shall 
put on web pages every so often so that you can use the results if you want.
An example is the kroma thing I did.
I try to do a Charlie Darwin on it - natural selection or something.
Imagine a peasant in south asia...... name of  Andrews 
Killingham-Winton...... he knows only his own dialect but has a pocket 
Glosa/his dialect dictionary. He is having trouble with his crop and is 
asking a scientists .....Ping Pong of northern Europe for advice PP knows 
only his own language and also has an apropriate G dic.
(I did ask my printer to print out the internet G dic, it remarked that I 
must be joking - there were 92 pages!!)
 Among the symptoms were yellow leaves. When AK-W looked yellow up he found, 
as youknow from "Kroma", 6 words. This is where CD comes in..... Xanto has a 
double consonant cluster "nt" and a one and a half cluster begin K+s for "X". 
Now, some south asians as far as I know don't like double consonants so 
"xanto" got naturally selected out! Safro's "fr" was more acceptable but 
"leuko" with CVCV was naturally selected in and used. 
(If  I remember correctly, there are about 17000 or so entries in the IND, if 
there are on average 3 choices for the same English word and they are prunes 
to one, the IND shrinks to about 6000 !!)
(As far as I am concerned, I suspect I normally use about 4000 different 
concepts [ go, went, going, goes, gone etc are all variants of the one 
concept] so there are probably quite a few expressions etc in IND that  I am 
not likely to use much so my core dictionary could be quite small)
AK-W's crop had a local name like "lords and ladies" for instance so that he 
had no idea what it was. Obviously they need to use the scientific names as 
inculing them in the core d would make it impossibly long.

addresses of your dictionary websites. I'd like to compare them with what I'm

sorry about my burbling on but it will give me a chance of adding more glosa

At 14:44 27/09/2000 +0400, Alexander wrote:

>Saluta, karo Robin, e karo plu Glosalist-pe!

>

>

>  1. I think in Glosa.

>No. I am trying, but now I can think only very primitive sentences

> 

*   Concentrate on getting the simple sentences fluent, then start expanding these with expanded phrasing, then start thinking of adding clauses.

   

>2. Irregularities in the vocabulary prevent me from writing

>                   in Glosa.

>No, when I'll have translated Glosa dic. into Russian, I'll try to write

>only in Glosa.

*   Nice to hear.  I feel that we can see the language through the spelling

maze.


> 3. A lack of clear-cut guidelines on syntax prevent me from

>                   writing in Glosa.

>No, I think that Glosa hasn't difficult syntax.

*   That was the intention: syntax is supposed to be fairly standardised in Glosa.  How would you think of teaching the rules of syntax?

    If this interests you, ask me to send the "G-ASCII Analysed Syntax" scheme: can you imagine teaching syntax in the abstract?


> 4. I do write in Glosa and am confident that I am using

>                   standardised sentence form.

>No.

>___|___|___  

*   Unless sentence style is taught and drilled, I suspect that learner will have to observe written Glosa, and 'intuit' the way sentences are put together in Glosa.  This was the method I used; however, by treating Glosa as a "concept language", i.e. one in which the abstractions of communication are paramount, I developed a feel for articulating the concepts.  Most languages facilitate a "concrete" approach to the juggling of 'things', objects, actions and descriptions.


> 5. I do write in Glosa, but am in a state of subjective

>                   uncertainty over my usage.

>Maybe.

>

*   The only way to jump the hurdle of developing subjective confidence is to get feedback on your use of the language.  For learning glosa, this means attempting to write in Glosa, and inviting others to make comments. 


> 6. As far as I know, my Glosa usage is correct, but I could

>                   be in error on some points.

>No, my Glosa usage now isn't correct.

*   With such knowlege, the trick is to put your 'inexact' sentences on the Glosalist and asking others to look at how you have done it, IE

  Kron tu grafo uti Glosa, don u sekunda line te monstro tu tende.

(when you write using Gl. give a second line in-order-to show your interntion) 

  [When you write in Glosa do a second line to show your intention.]


> 7. Sometimes when attempting to use Glosa, I find that there

>                   are some ideas I feel unable to express in Glosa.

>Yes

*   It was a shock to me, when I first discovered such an inability to find a way of expressing a particular idea.  I am not talking about vocabulary deficiencies, though these can be very annoying, I suggest that it might seem impossible to get your mind around some particular combination of ideas, Glosa-wise.  I used the 'tell-a-story' method at first: I think of this as the "discursive" way of using language; if pushing a small number of words together does not produce a satifying rendition of your idea, then the concepts involved might need to be teased out to make a more long-winded, descriptive senternce.  

   Eventually, after doing this exercise a few times, you can start to recognise concept-heavy ideas coming up, and then, mentally, you start teasing the ideas apart before you come to actually speaking or writing.



> 8. A better dictionary is needed before I can feel happy

>inattempting to use Glosa.

>possibly.

*   For some people this was an insurmountable barrier to using Glosa.  But, working on vocabulary projects, as you have done, certainly raises your awareness of the usage of the different words.  

   For example, in thinking about the Glosa "water" synonyms, aqa (L.) and hidro (G.), I came to realise that water was not only the clear stuff you get out of a tap, but that there were many ways of thinking about 'water.  So, I came up with a range of 'water' situations and then tried out aqa and hidra, alternately, in these situations.  Perhaps it can be thought of as letting the feel of the word, in the mouth, decide your usage.


> 9. An instruction manual is needed before I can feel happy

>                   in attempting to use Glosa.

>Maybe.

*   It would certainly be a good idea, but originally Ron was not in favour of rule-based learning for Glosa; instead, he suggested more the "do as I do" method.

    One of the main reason for Glosa's slow development could be this lack of specific instruction on the fine-points of usage and sentence construction.

    While Glosalist members are taken up with refinements to the lexicon, we are not using our abilities to move on to the next step .. of specifying the rules behind the language, and forming traditional exercises for learners to go through, to practice them.


> 10. A basic grammar book will improve my use of Glosa.

>Yes.

*   This was my reason for attempting to produce one.

    I got good advice from other members of the planned language Mailing Lists during the process, and attempted to modify the tabulation of Glosa Grammar to include the suggestions.

    I think I included it on my website.  By inspection of written Glosa, any other observer could abstract a similar set of usage rules, and make his,or her, own 'Glosa Grammar.'


> 11. A basic grammar book is needed before I can feel happy in

>                   attempting to use Glosa.

>No.

*  This is a fortunate answer, because, at present such an *official* Glosa Grammar does not exist.  However, your response is 'correct' in that the usage is so regularised and standardised, that the inherent rules can generally be perceived and applied without taught instruction.


> 12. I can understand the structure of the language through

>                   observation of printed Glosa texts.

>Yes, but I don't believe.

*   Is this a suggestion that because you use the language spontaneously and intuitively, and feel you are doing so correctly, though you cannot be certain that you have absorbed all of the rules through using this 'observational' method of learning?


> 13. There are aspects of the language I seek further information on:

> Imperative, and structure of questions (Is there difference in usage >question-words in beginning and in other parts of a sentence?).

>

*  Well asked.

   To standardise the use of the interrogative, the Glosa authors favoured a simple indication that a following statement should be taken as a question, by placing the 'flag, ~qe~, before the statement.

   However, the authors included a range of other "question-words" in the dictionary as well, because a speaker does not always want to reveal his question at the beginning of his sentence, or, perhaps, not even realise that he intends to put his information into the form of a question, until after he has started the sentence.  Most of these are found under "Q" in the dictionary, and were well covered in _Glosa Classified_. 

  ~Qe, an akti uno-ra?~

  (question: he does something)   ..  more, or less, means,

  "Is he doing something?"


  However, this pattern falls down if you want know what a person is doing.

  ~An akti qod?~ seems better than ..


  ~Qe, an akti qod?~,  ~Qe, qod akti an?~,  ~Qe, qod an akti?~ or ~Qod akti an?~.


   And then if we are looking for something, we could say,

 ~Qe, tu ski id loka?~  -- for "Do you know where it is?"


However, ~Qo-lo u ra?" and "Qe, u ra habe qod loka?~  don't seem as good.  We can try raising the question after making a statement, EG

   ~Memo un argenti; tu pa habe pa-di: qo-lo id habe nu?~.


   So, there probably are no rules .. beyond the the way the question feels comfortable for you.  The best way to reach a comfortable question format that is meaninful to others, as well, is to practise asking the same question in a number of different ways.

  

    I do apologise for not using Glosa to respond to your post, and also for not answering two months ago.


Saluta,


Robin Gaskell

Dear Alex
I too find Glosa not as easy as it seems and have often had difficulty 
understanding some parts of PGN. However that also applies to English and to 
Hindi/Urdu and other languages I've tinkered with.Often with Glosa, I am not 
sure which is the verb(to have, to follow etc). See what you think of the 
following:-
Nu-di mana, u fo pusi obesi andro ko longi e melani trika pa tako sed gentile 
dona plu kloro avi a u an gina.
In Glosa the verb phrase is somewhere near the middle, like English but 
unlike Hindi (at the end) or Welsh (at the beginning [I think]), you can find 
the phrase by finding the word "pa". This word announces the beginning of the 
phrase and also indicates time. The end of the phrase is at the beginning of 
the next one, the word "plu". The signals for the start of a VP (verb phrase) 
are "pa", "fu", "nu" sometimes and "du". Unfortunately,the VP does not have 
this signal and this is often where I get lost.
In Glosa, the words in a group  like "tako sed gentile dona" tend to become 
more important towards the end and add precision to the last word's meaning. 
There are all sorts of ways one can give; willingly, reluctantly......... and 
so on and here the author has added "gentile" as an adverb ( makes the verb 
more precise) and also "tako". The conjunction"but" makes the status of 
"tako" and "gentile" equal and draws attention to the apparent contradiction 
in the two term's meaning.
In Glosa, the subject noun phrase normally is in front of the VP, this one is 
signalled by the beginning "u" and the end is where the VP begins .
u fo pusi obesi andro.........
ko longi e melani trika.........
"longi" and "melani" are connected with "e", they are both as important as 
each other and they both make more precise the meaning of "trika". The hair 
is both black and long.
The "ko" joins this group to "andro" and adds more precision as it is his 
hair.
There is no "and" or "but" before "andro".
"obesi" adss precision to "andro" - he is fat, "pusi" adds precision to the 
following word "obesi"- he is slightly fat, the "fo" adds to " pusi" so he is 
very slightly fat. 
"plu kloro avi" starts with "plu", the next phrase starts with "a u", this is 
all after the verb and is the direct object of the verb.
"a u an gina" This is the indirect object of the verb
He gave the birds to the woman
"kloro" adds precision to "avi", "u an" (the his) to "gina"
Actually, this looks very like the subject "u andro ko trika" and "u avi a u 
gina" but the meaning makes the construction clear. I am not very happy with 
that state of affairs and need to ponder.
"Nu-di mana," This phrase can be omitted without radically affecting the 
meaning of the sentence, it expresses time as does the verb and could become 
pa nu-di mana e tako sed gentile dona . This would be clumsy and, as there is 
only one verb phrase and it is clearly time, it can be moved to other places. 
The same cannot be done with "obese" as you would not know to which noun, 
"andro, trika,avi or gina" was obese.
Hope you can make something of all this, it has made me think .
syd

One more thing about multilingual word-lists: They should have
a neutral and easily-machine-parse-able format. The standard
way is by tab- (and/or comma-) separated columns, e.g. ...

	Glosa, English, Chinese
	equs,  horse,   ma2

In the many cases of synonyms, best is to duplicate the whole line.
One could also add comments, but only beyond the last column
and/or introduced by a "metacharacter":

	# here are various animal species
	hipo, horse, ma2, # Greek source
	equs, horse, ma2  # blah blah blah

I don't really like whole-line comments to be interspersed,
because they are not easily loaded into a spreadsheet.

* Hi Paul,
  With apologies for my non-activity of late.

  Sid's long files are matchings of French language words with the Glosa
1000 list.  He includes a number of French words with similar meanings to
the Glosa words, though not all could be termed synonyms.

  The French to Glosa list has the previous (Glosa to French) list
reversed, but not SORTed.
 
  I attach - in the body of the e-mail in 'text' (not word document form)-
the beginning of each to give you an idea of the full lists:-

attached, glosa/french dic
syd
a ( ad)...... A =====at
a ( ad)...... A =====to
a ( ad)...... Vers =====towards
a fini...... Finalement =====eventually
a latu...... De côté =====aside
a-kron...... Ponctuel =====punctual
a-kron...... Jusqu'à =====till
a-kron...... Jusqu' à =====until
a-nu...... Pourtant =====yet
ab...... Absent =====absent
ab...... Loin =====away
ab...... De =====from
ab...... De =====off
abili...... Capable =====able
